UPDATED: DEC 29, 2016 November 2nd, 2014 - Midnight Sun impressed me on sip one of the Panty Peeler, so I came into the Treat with high expectations. Dark and rich looking, it looks like a worthy brew to stand against a cold Alaskan night. The nose is full of pumpkin, true to the label featuring a manic, childrens storybook style of the gourd. I also smell apple cider, probably a function of the cinnamon and nutmeg smells, but its richer and more synthesized than simply smelling some spicy scents. The body is medium to medium-heavy in weight, and the flavor begins with a slow percolating swell of cocoa, pecan and molasses. It warms the mouth like a dose of bourbon, adding a beet toothsomeness near the mid-taste. The aftertaste is given over to raisins, which compete aggressively with the pumpkin. Through the journey the pumpkin style is always visible, and yet the flavor is dynamic and shifting, giving this a nice sophistication and engagement that too few vegetal brews have these days.

November 30th, 2012 - Midnight Suns trippel is a knock out, and based on that admittedly small sample size, I was excited to try the agglutinative stylings of the Imperial Chocolate Pumpkin Porter. Thats a lot of flavor profiles to pack onto one name. But the smell lends some credence to the label, showing off malty and sweet scents of pumpkin pie, cinnamon, clove and brown sugar, lending more to the pumpkin part of the label than the others. No chocolate found here, though it makes its appearance in the flavor, a darker type, and dusted with lots of spices, including those found in the nose. The palate is heavy, giving this brew some heft and seriousness, and the dark, malty core is layered with flavors of pumpkin pie, raisin and fig. The overall balance is quite good, making this an apt beer for someone looking for an engaging, spicy brew with reflections of pumpkin pie - a great drink for the Thanksgiving table. 7/3/8/4/14 3.6

A steady pour into my Sierra Nevada IPA glass produces a three finger thick, nicely brown tinged, tan colored head. The beer is a concentrated, dark-chocolate brown color that shows clear, brown-amber hues around the edges when held up to the light. The aroma smells of roasted grain, cinnamon, smoky roasted notes, deeply roasted nutty notes, and even some dark chocolate hints towards the finish.

The beer has a nice dryness to it, considering I was expecting a bit more sweetness from a beer that smells so rich. Rich dark chocolate notes meld with roasted coffee notes, and a roasted nutty, and burnt grain astringency. This has a rich dark maltiness to it that provides just a bit of sweetness, which is accentuated by a solid cinnamon note, and the chocolate note as well. The nuttiness reminds me of notes of roasted hazelnuts. This really does have a nice rich maltiness to it, smoky, richly roasted, and with a burnt caramel color. The body is nice and rich, definitely a sipping brew, but without being overly rich, and certainly not cloying. As the beer warms up a more phenolic edge starts to take hold; especially in the finish where a clove like character starts to mix with the herbal woody side of the hops, and brings out a bit more of the harsh side of the hops.

This is definitely a nice beer, it is rich and satiating without being overly sweet; this plays up the richness and smokiness, which is quite nice.

So, after purchasing and shipping off a bunch of these as extras in trades, I had to give this one a go...

$14 for bomber @ JBs in Spokane, WA
Poured to NB tulip.

A: Pours a dark, dark brown. Nearly opaque. Little to no head on vicious pour. Thin mocha film on surface that will grow to 1/2 finger with lively stir. Spotted lace on rim.

S: Plenty of cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves smell like they were folded into cocoa-ed creme fresh. This was then spread over a slightly charred pumpkin. Very sweet, pleasant, a bit too strong, probably would do well to sit on oak for a month or too to help combat the artificiality of the bouquet. Mellow it a bit. 

T: I wish they would have backed down a tad on the nutmeg and cloves, they seem to dominate this one a little too much. Theres plenty of cocoa remaining on the finish, and the spices seem to balance out a minute or two after the lingering dies down, and this moment of equilibrium satisfies my palate quite well. Too much to tweak to give it a four.

M: Great body on this one. Velvety feel with low carbonation allows for thorough assessment of the flavor profiles here. Slicks the tissue and leaves imprints of the ale on the palate. Nice feel.

D: This a good beer. As I mentioned, there are quite a few things I would tweak to help balance it out just a bit. A little too much nutmeg and clove for me. I would suggest to anybody who already loves pumpkin ales, but not to the newcomer.

Got a taste of 2008, infected? Gusher, big russet/cream head, slightly funky. Slightly sour, hint of bitter. 
2007 still ok, raisin, fish, smoke, coffee.

Bottle from Bottleworks. 

Pours dark and relatively thick without much head into my Eley Kishimoto tulip. Nose is pumpkin, spices, chocolate cake. Flavors are creamy cocoa, a hint of ash, wisps of pumpkin. Mouthfeel is full and rich, but with a hint of chalkiness detracting. Given that Im not a big pumpkin fan to say the least, Im really enjoying this. Its a beautifully crafted beer and that outweighs my slight distaste for pumpkin ale.

Traded bottle. This is definitely more stout than pumpkin beer. I actually got more of the spices and some bitterness from the cocoa nibs than I really did of the pumpkin. Very nice just not your typical -right-of-fall pumpkin ale.

Nearly black, slightly rubied....almost no head.
Cinnamon, nutmeg, Pumpkin pie filling scents.
Taste is rich chocolate/pumpkin and spice.
Very tasty...enjoyable.

Bomber received by my Secret Santa (winter 2012). Thank you joeneugs! Pours viscous black with a small fizzy mocha head that quickly dissipates while leaving a small trace on the glass. Smell is malty, tiny fruity and very spicy with roasted malts, high quality dark chocolate, dark roast coffee, cinnamon, nutmeg, chocolate spongecake, roasted pumpkin, liquorice fudge, moist soil, caramel, toffee, cloves and hints of alcohol and ginger. Taste is slightly sweet, slightly bitter, malty, tiny fruity and slightly spicy with roasted malts, high quality dark chocolate, cinnamon, dark roast coffee, vanilla fudge, sweet liquorice candy, pumpkin pie, black forest cake, alcohol, nutmeg, cloves, brown sugar, cinnamon buns, caramel, toffee, hay, moist soil, charred wood and hints of ginger and cocoa powder. Mouthfeel is round, soft, velvety, tiny roasted and spicy astringent and medium to full bodied. Finish is bitter, malty and slightly spicy with roasted malts, high quality dark chocolate, vanilla fudge, caramel, cinnamon, nutmeg, moist soil, chocolate cake, hay, roasted pumpkin seeds and hints of cloves, ginger, alcohol and sweet liquorice candy. Is gets slightly too spicy as the beer warms in the glass but all in all this is a spectacular porter with lots and lots going on. Its making spice/herb/vegetable look sexy and thats definitely something.
Bottle. Chocolate, cinnamon, and pumpkin malt aroma. Dark brown with minimal head. Sweet chocolate, cinnamon, nutmeg, and pumpkin malt flavor. Nice body. Delicious.

2011 bottle thanks to fear025. Always been a big want of mine as I am a huge fan of pumpkin beers. Pours a deep dark brown with a light tan/gray head that quickly disperses to a foam. Huge chocolate aroma slight nutmeg and cinnamon. Sweet front of the sip, spicy middle and a roasty finish. Really super tasty. A real treat. Lol.

Bottle 2012 - pours pitch black, very little head. Nose of malt, smoke, molasses, and spices. Smooth mouthfeel. Taste is dominated by malt. Dark chocolate and spice accents. Very small pumpkin presence. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From bottle, 2012 vintage. Nearly black color with tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, oakey bourbon, and baking spices. Taste is dark chocolate milk, vanilla, nutmeg, and roasted smokiness. Full-bodied and a lingering chocolate spice aftertaste, yet detect hardly any pumpkin.

22 oz. bottle shared by jsquire @ Natifest 12. Pours a dark brown color with a medium sized khaki colored head. The aroma is nice; sweet pumpkin notes, the usual spices, chocolate and toasted malts. The flavor has more of the same goodness; chocolate and toasted malts with fleshy pumpkin and spices. A nice blending of porter and pumpkin beer. Very drinkable and a real treat. See how I did that.

This was a good porter, filled with chocolate and spices. I was, however, disappointed when the pumpkin was overshadowed by the chocolate itself. I had pumpkin aroma on the nose, but not in the taste. I even let it warm for a few and still didnt get any pumpkin flavor.
Bottle, thanks Paul. Black with tan head. Spicy and slightly sharp aroma, lots of nutmeg. Taste of nutmeg, pumpkin, spices chocolate and cola. Slighty sweet with a lingering nutmeg finish.

Bottle courtesy of ericdevin. Sweet lactic cocoa and light vanilla and spice aroma - really no pumpkin to speak of. Black brown with a small tan head. Sweet chocolate, cola, vanilla, and vegetal flavor with a light dusty-roast finish. Full body, soft carbonation.

Bottle, care of Vinny. Slit with Vinny, Janine, and my Dad. Pours mahogany with a very small bit of tan, quickly-receding head. Aroma of dark chocolate, clove, vanilla, and just a trace of pumpkin. Flavor is dominated by clove, nutmeg, and chocolate, with bit of pumpkin and vanilla in the mild finish. Very thin, weak palate, especially given the heft of the flavors this beer is attempting to support. I did not much care for this beer, as it way way too dominated by the spices and too lacking in chocolate and pumpkin flavor, as well as body.
Mäktig och krämig. Viss strävhet och kaffetoner. Aska. Pepparkakor. Kul bärs inför kvällens höjdpunkt...
Pours dark and thick with essentially no head. Weak aroma of chocolate and pumpkin. Definite pumpkin and chocolate flavors, but not exactly fantastic. Average beer

Nice, light brown head. Mostly clear dark brown color. Decent lace. Aroma is very veggie-like, not as rich, roasty, or sweet as I expected. Satisfying pumpkin aroma, though. Good, light carbonation. Dry finish. Light smokiness. Bitter taste, light sweet. Not what I expected

Bottle to flute.
Pumpkin, nutmeg, malt. Dark brown with a thin tan head. Taste is pumpkiny, almost cloyingly sweet and malty.

Bottle - Clove, pumpkin and pie like crust.  Black with at thin brown head.  Pumpkin, nice spaces and , toasted malts, some cocoa, no bitterness and a nice long finish.  Great pumpkin beer, but definitely for the end of the night.

A - Dark brown-black with a finger of frothy chocolate-khaki head atop. Fades fairly quickly.

S - Roasted caramel and chocolate malts, pumpkin, clove, cinnamon, nutmeg, and other spices, cocoa nibs, coffee, touch of booze.

T - Roasted chocolate and caramel malts, pumpkin, cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, other spices, molasses, cocoa nibs, coffee, dark fruits, and a touch of booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Great pumpkin porter. Good balance.
Dark honey pour from at dark lord day. Weird taste but good. Would like to try this sober

The label says it all on this one. All ingredients are apparent and well balanced. It's just yummy. One of my most preferred pumpkins. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours jet black with no head. Aroma of natural pumpkin, chocolate and caramel malt. Taste follows, less spice more pumpkin, very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Definitely a different take on the pumpkin ale craze by going way of stout.  The chocolate and the stout profile flavors took over and I only got glimpses of the pumpkin flavoring/spice additives.
Had on draft at the brewery. Chocolate, creamy, cinnamon, fruity alcohol, spiced chocolate cake. A good spiced beer.

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of Armin. Thanks man! Pour is pitch black with a creamy tan head and good lacing. Big sweet potatoes, cinnamon, nutmeg, light cocoa, oak, and a touch of vanilla in the aroma. Taste is spice, nutmeg, pumpkin pie, cinnamon, dark chocolate, graham crackers, marshmallows, and oak with a lightly spicy finish. Creamy mouthfeel with low carbonation. Nice pumpkin beer.

Bottle @ Stephens house courtesy of arminjewell. Thanks! Pours a black appearance with a brown head. Spicy nutmeg, toasty bready, mild caramel, mild pumpkin, chocolate aroma. Dark chocolate, lightly toasted pumpkin, nutmeg, cinnamon, vanilla, spicy flavor. A little chewy. Solid but nothing super special.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, dark black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of toffee, dark chocolate, hints of pumpkin, spice, cinnamon, vanilla, slight earth, pretty nice.  Taste is a mix of chocolate, coffee, roast, nice sweet pumpkin, toffee, vanilla, hints of spice with cinnamon, finishing fairly sweet and bitter.  Nicely done.

Bottle poured a very dark brown in color with a thin coating of tan head. Aroma has light spice, faint pumpkin, and porter malts. Mouth feel is medium and there is average carbonation. Flavor does have a porter at its core mixing with spices, cola, toasted chocolate, and light pumpkin.

Pumpkin and chocolate flavor. Interesting. It was good but I was expecting more. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Olive Tree: Appeared a dark brown liquid topped with a decent layer of foam head. Aroma was subtle yet had noticeable notes of spice such as cinnamon, nutmeg, and clove but I was unable to pick up any characteristics of cocoa or chocolate. The drink has a mild taste of roast malts but allows more room for the cocoa nibs to become more apparent while only a minor taste of pumpkin spices coming through. In my opinion, this isnt a solid attempt at the imperial porter style.

From notes - black pour, thick with full two finger tan head.  Nose is bananas? (Ive been informed by my girl that im to write magic bananas like the water cleaner commercial).  cloves, chocolate, minimal pumpkin... boozy.  Flavor is bananas up front, cloves and cinnamon, pumpkin and roasted malts.. sweet and bitter chocolate, richness.  Medium body with little lacing,.

Bottle with 2yrs on it.  Black pour with mocha head that lasts a blink if an eye. Nose is a little faint from the age but you do pick up the cloves, chocolate, roast and allspice.  Taste follows the nose but add a little more spice and chocolate.  Very smooth with little bite of any kind.  A little thin for a porter but tasty.

Pours thick and black with a fleeting tan head.
The aroma is gingerbread cookie dusted with powdered sugar.
The flavor is pumpkin, pie spice and finishes with a spicy tartness.
Interesting and tasty; just not the kind of beer I will drink often.

Bottle at ChrisO Holiday Tasting, London - thanks to Colin for this rarity. Pours thick black with a creamy, beige head. Dark malt nose with hints of gourd and light spices. Medium to big sweet flavor, heavy on the dark malts with background pumpkin and mild, earthy bitterness. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Sweet finish with rich bread, gourd and pumpkin sugars, light roast, mellowed dark malts. Super drinkable.

22 oz. bottle served in a Midnight Sun chub. 2012 vintage. Thanks to mfavoino for the share.

A: Pours a dark black color with some brown edges. A tan head forms on the pour and recedes slowly to a thin ring. Some splotches of lace are left behind.

S: Pumpkin, cinnamon and some oaty malts. Bakers chocolate with some roasted malts as well. The roast is deep.

T: The taste was a let down. Very earthy and bark like with some vegetal like flavors. Minimal chocolate with some light roast. Pretty much dominated by the earthy and vegetal flavors.

M: Medium bodied with a smooth carbonation level. OK light roast finish.

O: The nose was nice, but the taste was overpowered by this earthy-like quality and some vegetal like flavors. Lacked the porter backing I needed. A miss for me, but glad I got to try it.

Serving type: bottle

I got this one in the October raffle basket  at THE LOCAL BER BAR in Eureka, CA.  Pours jet black with a robust light tan head and a lot of lacing.  The nose is a blast of pumpkin and chocolate. Very full in body with a good smooth creamy mouthfeel. The flavor is very rich with a lot of he pumpkin and chocolate that was in the aroma,  The finish is delightful, with pumpkin pie spices with cinnamon and nutmeg.  Simply sumptuous.

Bottle at ChrisO tasting, thanks to Frank/Ramnuts for gifting me this one, 30/12/12.
Very dark mahogony brown/light black with a thin tan head that clears to the edge and leaves a few bubbles.
Nose is dark malts, dark fruit, spice, sugars, molasses, licqourice.
Taste comprises sweet sugars, pumpkin, ripe fruits, dates, chocolate, figs.
Full end of medium bodied with soft carbonation and some bitter sweetness in the finish.
Good stuff.

text: Bottle opened on NYE with the wife since we have a 2 year old and thus dont go out on this lame ass holiday. Pours a jet black with soapy khaki head. Aroma is pumpkin forward, slight cinnamon and slight burnt coffee. Taste is very pumpkin and chocolate with some light burnt smoke flavors in there. I wish I liked coffee. The pumpkin really plays well here. Liking it more and more as it warms. Wow. Might up the rating before I finish this off.....or....

text: On the (my) Twetfth day of Christmas the beer gods gave to me.... Number 900!   One that has evaded me for some time.   Lets rate his bad boy.  Pours a dark black color with an off white soapy head.  Aroma of chocolate, caramel, and vanilla with subtle notes of pumpkin spice. A slight roast in there too.  Sweet roasty taste with caramel and chocolate notes.  Spice through the finish.  Nice medium to thick body.  Just an excellent beer.  A crispness from the Alaskan water.  Wow.  This one you enjoy to the last drop.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2014 Bomber from trade with michaelinwa.  Pours a near pitch black color with a small head that fades quickly.  Aromas are cocoa, chocolate, pumpkin and some spices.  Taste is very dry cocoa, figs, and dates with hints of pumpkin and spices.  Surprisingly Im not a big fan of this.  Its very dry and pretty thin too.  Lots of potential from the aromas but overall its pretty disappointing.  Re-rate - 11/1/14 - Thanks to northernbrews for the share.  Better than I remember but not great.  Nice chocolaty aroma with light to moderate spices and dark fruit.  Taste has lots of spiced chocolate too with some pumpkin, cream, and light caramel.  Thin to medium body.  Solid pumpkin beer.
Spice and chocolate aromas. Flavors mimic the aromas. Overall a very good imperial pumpkin beer.
Bottle at Chriso tasting new year 2012/13.  Black beer with only some spice. really tasty. some paper on finish.

Bottle at Chrisos tasting in London, 121230. Pitch black beer with a brown/beige head. Chocolate aroma, pumpkin, sweetish herbal, caramel, roasted, raisins, floral, coriander, figs. Chocolate and licorice flavor, caramel, pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg notes, lots of spices, raisins, figs, floral and herbal notes. Really nice and with balance on the spices.
Tasted the pumpkin and spices, lots of chocolate, tastes like Halloweens! Sort of candy corn and chocolate. Would like too enjoy this while passing out candy. Really a good beer.

On tap at The Hop.  Lets hear it for adventurous beer!  Pumpkin, chocolate, and pie spices - nicely balanced and flavorful.  It is so smooth and tasty that its radical creativity could pass unnoticed.  Damn good - hope to come across more of this someday!

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2013 Along with Pumking, my favorite pumpkin ale.

Nice medium, creamy body, deep dark brown with russet highlights, spicy, chocolate nose with vanilla, Mil;k Duds, sandalwood, nutmeg, cinnamon, clove, and pumpkin.

Finish is long on the palate, and there is some drying in the finish from the modest, earthy hopping. Very nice stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2014 2012. Pumpkin husk, chocolate, nutmeg-spicy aroma. Really pungent and nice. So much going on here -- TREAT has complexity in spades. One of my fav annual seasonals; just the right balance of flavors. Would happily drink this year round; delicious.

Thanks, Mom! Having had a chance at the oak-aged version first, I was stoked to try the base out. A hefty dark brown porter at the base, this one had a fine chocolate nose with a bit of pulp, some roasted seeds, and a nice blend of moderate spicy notes in the nose. Thick, sometimes oily mouthfeel is groovy, and theres just a smidge of heat on the finish. Understated pumpkin guts and loads of choc in the taste, with nutmeg and a touch of modest pepper to me. Milky flavors come across just a bit too, giving this one the pronounced feel of a dessert beer. Yummy.

Bottle thanks to 5000.  Dark brown, almost black, with a small light brown head.  Aroma is pumpkin and pumpkin pie spice, chocolate, coffee, caramel.  The taste is fantastic,  a perfect blend of stout/porter roasted flavors, and pumpkin/spice, just the right amount of sweetness.  Finish is spice and roasty bitterness.  Medium bodied, well carbonated for the style/abv, silky smooth texture.  Yummy.

12 bottle.   Black pour with a layer of dark tan foam which quickly fades to a slick.  Aroma is roast, chocolate, spices, light pumpkin, and coffee.  Taste is vegetal spices with roast, chocolate, coffee, and light bitterness through the finish.  Light and clean mouthfeel.  Doesnt really taste like pumpkin per se but the beer certainly has the holiday spice thing going on with a dark, roasted porter flavor.  Good beer and I appreciate that its sub 10% ABV.

Pours thick and dark with a small tan head. Nose is big chocolate, pumpkins, nutmeg, cinnamon and light chocolate. Taste is richly sweet with a decent hop backbone to keep it in check. Still very decadent. The mouthfeel is soft and creamy, body is heavy an the finish is long.

Pours a dark brown with a brown head and aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and spices. Taste is sweet, of chocolate, roasted malt, spices, and pumpkin with a sweet, long, spicy finish. Delicious beer that tastes great.

Pours a lush dark brown black color, with small head. Nose is chocolate and holiday spices, nutmeg, cinnamon and allspice....quite a pleasant nose. Taste is spicy sweet with chocolate and some cloves. Carbonation soft with a heavy texture. Finishes with the same flavors, warms your palate. Quaff Score 8 / 10
Beautiful black pour.  Aroma and flavor of malty pumpkin, chocolate and caramel.  Rich smooth and yummy.  This one blew away the other 19 pumpkin beers of the evening.

On tap at Fulton Grand 11/03/2012 with Erica. Pours dark with a tan head into goblet. Very rich, sweet chocolate ... a tad roasty ... major breakfast notes of bacon/sausage grease and Bisquick. I dont really identify anything as overtly pumpkin, but there is a very good spice character nonetheless.

Bottle, 11/11/2012. Pours deep brown, black, thin tan mocha head with little retention. Aroma has porter-like chocolate roast malts, sweet pumpkin spice, cinnamon and nutmeg, caramel notes with subtle vanilla. Taste starts off with pumpkin, sweet maltiness, vanilla and spices, finishes with more traditional chocolate, roast coffee character. Medium full palate, lots of body. Not a bad pumpkin brew.

A - pours pitch cola brown with no head, no lacing. S - strong cacao nibs, spices (nutmeg, cloves) coffee, chocolate, cinnamon, cola syrup. M - med full body, not super complex. Lingering spicy maltiness. T - cola syrup, pumpkin, sticky rich malts, notes of spices, tangy cacao nibs, molasses, toffee. O - pretty good seasonal ale. 6+

Draft. Deep black . Chocolate, cocoa nibs and spice. Thick and syrupy like a shake. Exceptionally smooth porler

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2012 Rated two nights ago as part of our annual pumpkin beer night. Bomber. Pours opaque black with a collapsing tan head. Aroma is pumpkin pie spice, burnt caramel. Taste is sweet, savory, meaty, peppery and roasty. Has a real pumpkin flavor. Finishes lightly tart. Has a creamy mouthfeel. I like the fact that I can actually taste the pumpkin in this. A lot of pumpkin porters/stouts have little to no pumpkin flavor. Nice one.

Draught pour from Monks Kettle. Pours pretty much black with a one-finger dark mocha head. Nose is chocolatey, with notes of coffee, lactic notes, pumpkin, and mild spice. Similarly, the taste is not nearly as spicy as a pumpkin beers usually are. The porter really shines through here, with the pumpkin well integrated and as much like pumpkin itself as spices. Great combination. Seems like its boozier than 7.8%, though not in a bad way.

Black in color. Minimal tan head. Constallation lacing. Chocolate notes with a slight cinnamon follow. Creamy texture. As the beer opened up I smell smoke. Smooth chocolate finish. Loved the body of the beer. Best beer of the  night. Loved it.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2012 22 oz. bottle- Pours midnight black with a one finger tan head that reduces to a blanket. The aroma is smoked roasted malts, caramel, no pumpkin really, but a nice aroma. The taste is sweet roasted malts, creamy, somewhat tart, not getting much pumpkin again, but this is a nice beer, a really nice beer. I love it.
Great beer. Holiday pumpkin beer and you can get your stout on. Good for Halloween but thats about it.

From memory.. On draft at Original Gravity.. A solid, rich, full bodied, beer. Dense and dark, with heavy nuances of bakers spices (most notably cinnamon), deep chocolate, vanilla and definitely an impression of baked pumpkin. Thick and decadent, with pure, defined flavors. Nothing to complain about. Enjoyable. 

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...

S- Chocolate, nutmeg, fall spices, slight pumpkin, graham cracker

A- Pours as an Imperial Porter should. pretty black, off white/tan head.

T- Chocolate, spices, definitely nutmeg/cinnamon, light pumpkin, sweet, almost cloyingly sweet

P - Smooth, coats the mouth

O - Good Beer. Maybe a little too sweet, but I dug it overall. Dont Usually like pumpkin beers but within an Imperial Porter it was pretty good.

Pours very dark with a dark fluffy head. Nice aromas, superb mouthfeel, sticky, and sweet. Lots of chocolate, mild pumpkin notes, and well balanced hopping. I also get some dark fruit. A delicious brew. Tasted @ 60F.
Black/dark brown with medium head. Nose is pumpkin spice on top of coffee and cocoa. Flavor is same with a bit more emphasis on the cocoa, fading to coffee bitterness. Gets better as it warms up.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 Bottle from a shop within an hour that doesnât have a limit (thank God too because its amazing). So, to clarify some of the earlier reviews, itâs thinner than Arctic Devil and Berserker (their big beers), but not really thin compared to others. Aroma and flavor was of a relatively thicker porter with enticing pumpkin, chocolate, and clove. This is one of my favorite beers of all time...just an amazing beer.

A little on the thin side for mouthfeel, but big on taste. Not too heavy on the spice side, but good mix of pumpkin and spice

On tap @ The Beer Junction. Pours thin inky black with faint mocha head. Aroma is roasty chocolate malts and pumpkin spice. Big, rich chocolate, molasses taste, with roasted but not charred finish. Pumpkin flavor is subtle but present throughout. ABV is deceptive on this, not immediately evident.  Unlike other imperial pumpkin porters, this actually tastes big and imperial.

One of my favorite beers.  I first tasted it at Bodega fest in 2011 and was floored by it.  Nothing is better for a beautiful fall day.  It pours a dark black with a nice foam head.  you can smell the complex blend of spices immediately.  The taste has many layers to it.  You get hints of chocolate, pumpkin, clove, nutmeg.
A great scent. The cinnamon & nutmeg stand out. The flavor is delicious. You taste what you smell. To me the scent is more potent than the flavor. Its the best pumpkin style brew Ive had so far.

2011 bottle on year old today. Pours a black color with a tan head. Aroma is of cooked pumpkin, clove, ginger, cinnamon and cocoa, some roasted malt, coffee, dark caramel and doughy notes. The flavor is also of cooked pumpkin, and pumpkin pie spices, again clove, ginger and cinnamon, with the cocoa and chocolate notes, however they seem quite faded since this bottle is 1 year old, along with the roasted malt, doughy notes and dark caramel. The body is medium with a creamy mouth feel. Overall a pretty nice and different take on the Pumpkin Ale genre, I would love to try it fresh though.

Big thanks to Beerwolf77! #500

A: Pours pitch black with hardly any head. Little retention to speak of

S: Right off the bat, tons of molasses, fresh pumpkin puree, light clove and cinnamon, chocolate and lactose. The nose really gives you the pie/crust/whipped cream experience. Very nicely done

T: Tons and tons of molasses, chocolate, light clove (not overpowering), some cinnamon, and other spices. Again, lots of crust and pumpkin pie flavors coming through, less whipped cream. Raw pumpkin - some sweet and some raw

MF/O: Viscous, creamy, velvety feel. Lingering molasses finish. Absolutely awesome and unique- more drinkable than Pumking but less flavorful. Thanks again Todd

Bottle at Natifest 12. Poured cloudy brown color with a large off-white frothy head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Solid doughy pumpkin spice aroma. Medium to full body with a creamy texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy balanced pumpkin spice flavor with a medium spice sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Good beer.

Sample from a 22oz bottle at Natifest. Nice, light brown head. Mostly clear dark brown color. Decent lace. Aroma is very veggie-like, not as rich, roasty, or sweet as I expected. Satisfying pumpkin aroma, though. Good, light carbonation. Dry finish. Light smokiness. Bitter taste, light sweet. Not what I expected, but it really grew on me.
Bomber to taster at Natifest. Looks good; black with tan lacing. Smells solid; pie spice. Tastes GOOD! Like great pumpkin pie with a nice mouthfeel. Yes!
Bottle to CBS sniffter . Aroma of spice and chocolate pours black with tan head. Taste is pumpkin pie but chocolate coverd not to sweet too

Wow, what an amazing nose!  Smells like fall mixed with nutmeg, not the best beer Ive smelt but damn close.  I found this to by an very hyped beer that deserved all the hope-la!  What a rare treat.  Big thanks to Markwise for this this in trade.  Taste is nutmeg, cinnamon, and, yes, pumpkin.  Ive had man imperial pumpkin ales that spoke of pumpkin more strongly but this was hands down the best porter Ive ever had.  Definately worth the trade, worth the try.  Thanks again Mark.

Originally reviewed: 10/1/09. Vintage 2008.

Poured into my pint glass. Pours a very thick deep black. This is one of thickest porters Ive ever seen. No light coming through this one, not even on the edges. Small tan head caps this one off. Decent retention, but leaves little to no lace. Smells of pumpernickel bread, gingerbread, molasses, chocolate powder, milk, with a finish of roasted nuts. This is a smörgåsbord of scent! 

The mouth is creamy, yet wet. Not the smoothest, but not lacking in subtle bite either. Just right. These flavors mix ever so wonderfully. The pumpkin is there, but it is mild and tame. The chocolate is also there, but not in your face. This is balanced perfectly. Nice little bite from the hops right smack in the middle as well. Finishes roasted and bready. Dang. This beer sat me down and taught me a thing or two. I want more. Also, I think I may make a chocolate pumpkin pie this year. This was stellar.

Bottle sent from 12many and shared with several people.  
Ive been waiting a long time to give this one a shot and it did not disappoint.  Its very complex, with enough pumpkin and pumpkin pie spices to add to the depth without eclipsing the other traditional porter flavors. Hands down crushes any other "pumpkin" beer.  I would drink this on a regular basis, regardless of season, if it were easily available.  Good stuff that Im glad to have tried.

Bottle: Poured a dark black color porter with a nice medium brown foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of cinnamon and light roasted malt with some light pumpkin undertones. Taste is a complex mix between some cinnamons, some light dry roasted malt with some light pumpkin notes, some nutmeg and a nice rich black chocolate finish. Body is about average with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. This is quite a unique recipe with loads of complexity while retaining a good drinkability level.
Bottle thanks to Bigmmartin.  Aroma is strong with nutmeg and clove. Notes of roasted malts, cinnamon, allspice, and a tiny bit of hops.  Palate is smooth and creamy. Flavor is sweet finishing dry.
Date: March 24, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: DalzAle tasting Description: Dark brown pour with nice amount of head.  Aroma was clove, chocolate and cinnamon.  Taste was like a nice spicy pumpkin pie.

Bottle shared by Greg - thanks! Pour is dark with brown lacing and foam. Nose is clove and a little vanilla. Nice carbonation pumpkin chocolate and excellent spice. A unique blend, quite good!

Bottle thanks to TheGuy!  Dark brown cherry color, very little carbonation and a heavy clove nose with some lingering cinnamon.  Flavor is rich malty pumpkin, some vanilla, nice blended clove and vanilla.  Solid.
Bottle. Black pour with brown head. Chocolate, cinnamon and light pumpkin aroma. Velvet like texture. Sweet flavor, vanilla, chocolate and pumpkin .

22oz bottled August 2011.  Served at cellar temperature.

Pours dark brown to black with a small brown head that quickly fades to just a ring and leaves very short-lived spots of lacing.

Aroma is primarily spices, pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, also some chocolate and roasted malts.  Very good strength.

Flavor also features a lot of spices, pumpkin, cinnamon and nutmeg, but here the chocolate comes through a lot better than the aroma, a fair bit of roasted malts and a little dark fruit as well.  A bit of alcohol on the finish, but not too bad.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, creamy, sticky, medium carbonation.

One of the better spiced ales Ive tried...quite a treat!  The cocoa nibs add a nice layer to differentiate this from other spiced beers.  Mediocre appearance and mouthfeel hold the score back a bit.  Big thanks to my sister from Seattle for sending this my way!

From notes.  First reviewed 3/11/2011.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a tulip.

TREAT is a cocoa walnut brown, with a gentle foamy tan head that exhibits decent retention but does not leave much lace.

The aroma is mostly cocoa, then pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, and a touch of molasses.

Taste: The flavor really captures pumpkin pie with a dash of cocoa in it. It is quite artfully crafted. Cocoa in the malt is noticeable up front, then smooth pumpkin pie. The spices are there with the nutmeg, cinnamon, and maybe some all spice as well. 

This is fairly smooth, with a medium to full body and some bubbly carbonation. 

Drinking this immediately changes whatever environment you are in into post-Thanksgiving. The relaxed flavors work well together, making for an excellent sipper.
Bottle.  Pours brown with a tan head.  Aroma of pumpkin, chocolate, cinnamon and other spices.  Similar flavors, well done beer.
Aroma was more of fruit than pumpkin, but it did come through in the finish.
Pours a moderately dark brown with thin lacing. Infection noticeable in the aroma. Notes of pumpkin, Ginger, chocolate, spice and very heavy on clove.

Blind bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours clear dark brown with a ring of light tan head. Nose is Christmas spice, menthol, and some woodiness. Lightly roasty malt. Taste is sweeter, with a lightly nutty fruitness (cherry?) with light roast, cocoa, and no hoppiness to speak of. Thin body with a bit of powdery note. Well-carbonated. Not a big fan, and didnt get a lick of pumpkin out of it.

Pours solid black with a frothy brown head. Aroma of pumpkin and chocolate, not a ton of spice, but they are noticeable. Taste was funky and partially offensive when cold, but once it warmed, it was better. When cold, there was a lot of musty basement aroma and flavor, but as it warmed, it faded into more of cocoa and bitter pumpkin. the texture is decent, a little thinner than expected. Overall, not as good as I was expecting.

Bottle: black with a tan head. Strong aroma of spices and coffee.  Roasted flavors of coffee and cocoa.  It reminded me of the Mexican cocoa in one of my favorite mochas.  Earthy aftertaste of pumpkins and other squash. Lots of points for creativity. Quite complex.

Bottle thanks to my friend Jamie: Poured a black brown with little bubble head. Aroma was clove, spices, pumpkin, and chocolate. Taste was very delightful with nice warming clove and spiced pumpkin, and yet had a sweet chocolate malt finish.

Bottle from califan.  Thanks!    Pours deep brown with a big fizzy light brown tan head.  Aroma of rich lotent roast, smoke, dark chocolate,pumpkin themed spice mixture.  Nice balance between bright between bitter fresh roasted coffee, chocolate, and muddledpumpkin mix spice.  Velvety body.   Tight aroma.  Real nice.

Into Duvel tulip from bottle. Pours very dark with finger of tan head. Smell is rich pumpkin spice. Not a lot of traditional porter smells. Taste is strong pumpkin, bit of coffee and chocolate. More balanced than some of the other pumpkin porters Ive tried. Smooth. Very good, probably my favorite Midnight Sun

From the makers of the disgusting Coffee Porter (Arctic Rhino) I just finished, comes another Special Porter, this time a Chocolate Pumpkin Porter. Once again, it looks great, smells funky, but this one doesnt taste like soap. Its basically plain, but there is some noticeable traces of Pumpkin, no Chocolate that I am aware of though. Its very good though. I only wish I could have had this 2 months ago when it was in season.

Are you kidding me with this beer.  Just DELICIOUS.  Pours jet black and viscous into a tulip with rich tan head.  Aroma is beautiful spiced and you can get a great rich chocolate on the nose.  The taste is multi-layered and amazing.  It starts with a rich roasty chocolate porter that fades towards the end of the taste just in time for a great spice combination to fill in and finish the beer.  Thanks to SuzyGreenburg(Ben) for this fantastic extra.

Bomber thanks to ben greenburg. This is an amazingly
Complex Blend of ofFlavors on the nose and palate. Big creaminess from the chocolate. The spices and pumpkin are perfectly balanced. I wish I could buy this

Appearance:  Pours black with a reddish hue. Atop sits a decent tan head.

Aroma: Chocolate, roast squash and holiday spices.

Taste: Dark Chocolate,tree bark, roasted pumpkin meat.

Mouthfeel:  Full with active carbonation.

Overall: An amazing pumpkin beer. As for dark pumpkin beers, this one is king. Think pumpkin bread/cake with chocolate chips!

Aroma is very smoky roasted malts with the fall spices shining through nicely. Pours dark solid chocolate chestnut with a decent caramel head. The flavor is big notes of chocolate and fall spices blended together.

250th rating of this beer. I thought this was my 4600th rating, but apparently I dont know how to count, so its actually 4599. Bottle shared at the 6th annual Richmond Industry Gathering, 11/27/11. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a thin creamy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of big pumpkin and squash notes, earthy and peppery notes and roasted malts. The taste is tart pumpkin notes, spices, roasted malts, chocolate, earthy hops. Medium bodied. Nice.

22oz bottle.  T-day beer #3.  Ive been sitting on this one for a year.  Nice poerterish color, deep brown/black hue.  Aromas are sweeter almost like overly vegetal pumpkin, getting me slightly worried.  I think what holds this one together is the cocoa up front otherwise it would have been a one dimensional mess.  Extremely light and smooth on the palate, with a boozy finish.  I think I want this fresh, still good, but could have been greater I think.

Poured  into my Double Bastard Tall Glass, black with a Tan head that lasted through three-quarters of the glass and left nice lacing all the way to the last sip. Very pleasant aroma of pumpkin, chocolate, light roast, and a hint of coffee. The flavor is complex with the pumpkin and chocolate as the main tastes, but with coffee, light roasted malt, also present. I did not taste much of the spices listed in the description. But this still was an amazing beer. Medium to heavy bodied. But it did get a little sweet towards the end, Especially after drinking the whole 22 oz. bottle. I planned on sharing with 2 of my friends, but after drinking a Weyerbacher Pumpkin Ale, Lagunitas Sucks" and a Goose Island Christmas ale on thanksgiving, I couldnt stop myself. Fairly smooth at the finish. Having something that you have wanted for a while can be a let-down after all the hype. Thankfully in this case, the experience lived up to my expectations.

Bottle; Pour is dark brown with a khaki head on the average side - light, spotty lacing is present in this tulip. Well - The infamous T.R.E.A.T is finally in my grasp. I really didnt know exactly what to expect - the nose is heavier on the spiciness than I expected, that is for certain. The cloves dominate, coupled with the nutmeg, cocoa. What happened is that I completely forgot that this was supposed to be brewed with pumpkin for a while; the flavor profile is at once bitter, sweet, and spicy. The cinnamon and chocolate bring in the sweetness, naturally. While there is a certain roastiness from the base beer here - this is an interesting brew, for sure.

2010 bomber from superdave consumed 2/13/11.

importer color with  a soft tan head. the foam clings for quite a while to the inside of the glass.

pumpkiny nose... also, choco, pie spice (especially clove and nutmeg), black pepper, oily vanilla, brown sugar and roast.

the flavor is heavy on the spices... pumpkin, cocoa, nutmeg and vanilla play second fiddle. pie spices really linger for a long time.
it is thicker and a lot more chocolate-y than 4p pumpkin but it is also a lot more spice driven. 8/4/7/4/15

[Tap] Tried this at the brewery in mid-September. Pours a deep brown color with a beige head on top. Malty aroma of cocoa and roasted grains. Hints of nutmeg and clove comes out in the nose as well. The taste is of heavy roasted malt, chocolate, nutmeg, ginger, pumpkin spices and earthy notes. More clove is apparent as it warms. Oily mouthfeel despite a moderately high carbonation level. Good balance considering how much is going on here. Tasty and rich!

Bomber. Black with a half-inch of dense mocha head. The aroma is a potent mix of roast pumpkin, nutmeg, bittersweet chocolate and allspice. The taste starts off with a blend of dark chocolate, pumpkin pie filling and toasted bready malts upfront followed by cinnamon, cardamom and cloves. Also some more chocolate and espresso notes right at the end. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with light carbonation while the finish is sweet and roasty with a shot of allspice. Overall, a rich and flavorful blend of chocolate, pumpkin pie and dessert spices that makes for the perfect accompaniment to All Hallows Eve.
Pours dark black. Aroma is intriguing. Not just one note. Flavor is primarily chocolate with some slight spice notes

2010 bottle.  This is one Ive wanted to try for the fall season but by the time I got it last year I was pretty much done with the pumpkin beers, so I decided to wait until now.  The aroma is as expected with the pumpkin, milk chocolate, nutmeg, ginger, and perhaps a slight touch of cinnamon.  Deep brown colored, this pours with a thin tan head on top.  Not much lacing.  This is pretty tasty stuff; smooth long milk chocolate flavor thats joined by pumpkin spice, cinnamon, and nutmeg.  Theres no mistaking the cinnamon here, and the chocolate seems to stand toe to toe with the pumpkin spice.  I like how the pumpkin isnt overly dominant, and theres no over the top crusty cracker pumpkin pie thing going on, like most of the pumpkin beers seem to have.  This is a "style" I may never truly embrace but this is a good one.

2008 bomber.  This was a colossal gusher.. I probably lost half the beer.  Eventually poured very deep brown with a tall cap of dark tan head.. sticky lacing followed it down.  The aroma picked up a lovely blend of cinnamon, cloves, and dark chocolate with more spices, pumpkin meat, and very dark honey behind.. some sourness throughout, but not by any means in a bad way.  The flavor opened with tart roasted chocolate and lesser medicinal notes, with pumpkin meat and more dark chocolate behind.. cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg were pervasive and complementary.. finished with a lot of chocolate and spices, with a nice kiss of pumpkin.  Medium-bodied with way too much carbonation on the palate.. beyond that, everything worked well together.. overall a very good beer that Id love to try again.

Trade from Monsterzero, thanks. Pours dark brown with a medium light brown head. Aroma is nutmeg, chocolate, cinnamon and other spices. Flavor is nutmeg, peppar notes, chocolate, spices. This is a wierd but interesting brew. Medium carbonated.

Bottle, courtesy of Beerlando, thanks!. A clear dark brown to black beer, with a small, frothy, mostly diminishing light brown head. The aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate, caramel), with notes of spices, pumpkin, molasses and a touch of alcohol. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, soft/lively carbonation, long finish with about medium bitterness, lightly to moderately alcoholic. A good amount of spicy and pumpkin notes, not excessively alcoholic, with a good balance, on the sweet side, though. Very good.

wheres stumac? .. . Pours a medium brown black .. light medium foam .. . light spice, burnt molasses, pie crust, and light chocolate pumpkin candy . . amazingly subtle and balanced, worthy of the praise and paired nicely with the pumpkinator .. . . tilamook is tasty.

Bottle. Pour is black with a massive tan head, good lacing/retention. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, toffee, pumpkin, spice, clove, cinnamon, nutmeg. Wow, smells like fall. Taste is chocolate, coffee, pumpkin spice, cinnamon. Palate is creamy, oily, long chocolate finish. Definitely a solid fall beer.

650mL bottle poured dark brown into glass with big off-white head and lots of nice lacing.  Aroma is pumpkin, chocolate and some spices.  Taste is complex blend of roasted malty sweetness, pumpkin, chocolate and spices.  Very well done and highly recommended.  This beer is certainly unique.
(tap) very dark brown colour with small brown head; aromas of stewed and smoked fruit; thick palate; balanced flavour with long light bitter finish

Poured from a 22oz bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with off-white creamy head.  Aroma is pumpkin, cloves, ginger, nutmeg and just a hint of cocoa.  Taste follows the nose.  A really tasty fall offering.

Dark black pour. Small tan head. No lacing. Smells of cinnamon and nutmeg. Big aroma of coffee from roasted grains I suppose. Tastes of chocolate, cinnamon and nutmeg. Sweet and velvety. One of the second best pumpkin beers out there.

Bomber. Dark brown with a light brown head. Interesting - like a spicy pumpkin pie but in liquid form, cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin, but of apple and chocolate along with roasted grains. Sweet, well carbonated, very bubbly on the palate, bit of booze on the finish.

big thanks to oregonskibum 

poured into a wide tulip.

dark brown with the most smooth and creamy head I have ever seen, almost like a pour from a nitro tap....

the aroma is strong fall spices followed by the slightest bit of chocolate.

the flavor at first is spice and pumpkin. as it warms up the chocolate and the malt start to take over the mid and back palate with the pumpkin and spice being mainly in the front.

This is the best pumpkin beer i have ever had! Glad to know that it is coming to socal in a week or two!
Bottle shared by SuperDave @ RBWG Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is pumpkin and spices. Flavor is light pumpkin but heavier on spices and some chocolate. Nice beer.

Bottle This beer rocks! Pours pitch black with a small, creamy, beige head. Excellent retention. The aroma extends lavish chocolate intermingled with autumnal spices  cinnamon, clove, nutmeg  and pumpkin meat with a lovely vanilla nuance. Full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and soft carbonation.  The flavor is sweet, chocolaty and spicy, offering notes of brown sugar, cinnamon and graham. Like the oak aged version, despite all the residual sugar, at no point does the taste become cloying and, yes, its like drinking a liquid Smore with a dab of pumpkin pie filling stuffed in amongst all the chocolate, marshmallow and graham cracker. World class pumpkin beer!

Bottle shared by SuperDave @ RBWG.  Dave, you rock...been wanting to try this for a while.  Dark mahogany pour with a tiny eggshell head.  Nose of nutmeg, pumpkin, anise, cinnamon, and cocoa.  Flavor doesnt quite live up to the nose.  Decent amount of pumpkin spice along with chocolate.  Fairly creamy palate.  Good but I had such high expectations...just sounded soooo yummy.

Location: Bottle at Max and Andys Fantasy Tasting, 5/1/10


Aroma: The aroma has a lot of spice to it, but not too much pumpkin

Appearance: A dark brown-black pour with a fairly small head

Flavor: Taste is more chocolaty than the nose, but spice flavors as well

Palate: The body is fairly smooth and silky with low carbonation, medium to full

Overall Impression: 
Overall, I thought this one was pretty good, but it was quite as good as I had wanted it to be.  I would have liked a little more pumpkin in the spice, but all-in-all not bad.  The chocolate malts really come through in the flavor as well, though they are not nearly as prevalent in the nose.  In the end, this one is a solid offering.

Reviewed from notes. Thanks to both bmanning and Azurelimits for having opened bottles of this on separate occasions.

Pour is a midnight black with a low tan head and not too much lacing. The nose is really fantastic with some strong notes of chocolate as well as some clove, cinnamon, and nutmeg. A bit of actual pumpkin and mild sweetness in there as well. The taste mixes chocolate and pumpkin elements quite well. Really nice feel with the proper amount of spice interwoven with the chocolate. Nice and tasty; Id give about anything to try out the oak-aged version of this.

Serving type: bottle

22 oz. bottle from bobertkuekn- thanks again, Robert! 2010 vintage. Tried this side-by-side with a 2008 Oak Aged Imperial Chocolate Pumpkin Porter. Pours a dark opaque brown color with a small tan ring for a head- looks just like the OAICPP. Aroma of toasted malts, dark chocolate, nutmeg, cinnamon, brown sugar, and a little bit of dark fruit. Flavor of roasted malts, brown sugar, toast, coffee, dark fruits, nutmeg, and cinnamon. Medium-bodied, with a smooth, roasty mouthfeel and mild carbonation. Smoother and more subtle than the OAICPP, but not quite as exciting. Still an awesome beer in its own right, and really unique.

Bottle poured into my Narke glass, thanks to Mike...Black pour with some decent retention at first, but fades quickly. Light lacing...Interesting aroma that really captures the essence of pumpkin, has some spice and chocolate notes as well. Too much pumpkin for me, but its good...Taste is pumpkin pie on steroids, just terrible. If you like pumpkin then you will like this, if you dont you wont and skip it.

Bottle shared at RBWG 2011, thanks 
Appearance: Dark brown with a small tan head and some lacing 
Aroma: Dark fruits and spices 
Taste: Smooth mouthfeel of dark malts and fruits, cocoa and pumpkin spices 
Nice.

Thanks fear025. Pours dark brown with burnt copper edges and one finger of creamy light tan head. Nose is sweet and spicy with nutmeg and clove upfront and hints of milk chocolate and bread. Flavor is rich and spicy with a chocolaty character and mild bite. Clove and nutmeg on the finish with a full rich body

Bottle. Pours a ghastly pitch black, no head whatsoever. Aromas of cloves, cinnamon, pumpkin guts, sandlewood, opp, dark roasted cocoa nibs. Taste is just as pleasing with ginger pumpkin interwoven with rich chocolate. Lacing is very minimal. Some very slight smokeyness but overpowered by the amazing clove spicyness of the beer. Magical pumpkin porter from a truly incredible brewer.

22 oz bottle shared by Kan. Thanks! Pours a near pitchblack pour, near opaque, with a nice tannish head that dies to a thicker film. Laces ok. Aromas are a touch spicy, cinnamon and clove with a touch of nutmeg, vanilla. Light cocoa and coffee, touches of sweet caramel, toffee. Initial is medium to heavier bodied. Some flavorful sweet cocoa, pumpkin, and spicy cinnamon. Vanilla, pumpkin, cinnamon, clove, with proper spice, rich cocoa and coffee. A chocolate pumpkin porter, sufficient spicing, not towards the cloying end with a fuller cocoa and coffee element, good roast and toast, buit still some substantial chocolate, sweet caramel, toffee. Finish is lightly spicy, lingering roast, chocolate and pumkin spice. Quite tasty, complex.

Sampled at ITAP Big Black Beer Bash.  A huge pumpkin start.  Plenty of anise and chocolate, too.  Those leveled out almost too quickly and was replaced by some earthiness.  This is a Fall beer that meets Imperial Stout and it is a delicious combination.

Black poiur with a small creamy brown head.  Aroma of spice, pumpkin, roast and dark chocolate.  flavor is a bit sweet, roasty and lots of pumpkin, chocolate and spice.  Thick, creamy pallet.  Pretty good.

In short: As expected, a chocolaty beer with traditional pumpkin beer spices.  A superior example of this sub-style
How: Bottle 22oz.  Split two-way.  Exact age unknown, probably close to 1 year of age.  Bottle sent to me by brewolf, thanks a lot Michael
The look: Black body topped by a medium tan head
In long: Nose has a moderate amount of the usual array of pumpkin beer spices (cinnamon, nutmeg, etc.) over black chocolate.  Taste is chocolate, slick caramel, dark fruits, usual array of pumpkin beer spices, some vanilla.  Nice body that is big and full yet very silky.  Taste is not so chocolaty for a beer with chocolate in the name.  The typical pumpkin beer spices are not over-done here and are well integrated in the rest of the beer.  Im not much of a fan of this style of beer so my not-so-high rating just reflects my personal preferences.  But objectively, this is a very well made beer.  A nice Halloween beer to remind me that Halloween can be a lot of fun.  But because I live in a big city downtown loft I dont see funny dressed children doing trick or treat anymore.  Just funny dressed women offering tricks and Gonorrhoea.

Poured a completely opaque jet black, with a half-finger of finely bubbled head that didnt lace much and dissapated quickly. Smell is beautiful, with tons of cinnamon and nutmeg along with a touch of clove, and is accompanied by a soda-pop tart smell that is fantastic. Chocolate pumpkin comes in at the back. In between, some roasted malt to add still more complexity. One of the best smelling beers Ive had in a long while. Taste follows suit with the palate transitioning smoothly between spice, malt, and pumpkin. Starts with those spices of cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg, then moves a delectably roasted semi-sweet chocolate middle. Pumpkin then begins to rear its big fat orange head, eventually leading to a delicious roasted pumpkin milk coffee finish. Tastes so creamy it is almost milky. Mouthfeel is awesome, as the thickness and lesser carbonation yield a chocolate pumpkin milkshake of a beer. Drinkability is pretty damn good too, as the finish is actually kind of neutral when you take a step back. This is kind of a letdown compared to the rest of the beer, as I would have liked a strong aftertaste to let the beer linger after every sip, but everything else is too good to let that bother me too much. The fact that it finishes so clean, and hides the 7.8% abv so well, speaks the drinkability as well. Pumpkin beers perhaps should not be measured by this one due to its mesh of styles, but this definitely has set the bar for spiced beers in my mind. This probably faded a bit since the initial release, but I can see the flavors melding a bit better now than if it was fresh. Nonetheless, its going to be a long wait to try this fresh this year. Props Midnight Sun...mad props.
Poured very black, smooth, chocolate, pumpkin, roasted malts, little spice.

Poured into a pint glass. Big thanks to piclee for a chance to try this one.

3.5 A: Pretty much black in color. One finger of frothy light brown head with poor retention and only a touch of lacing.

4.5 S: Pumpkin pie hits you first. Theres some pumpkin as well as plenty of the pie spices: clove, cinnamon, nutmeg, cardamon. Chocolate next stemming from the cocoa nibs. The underlying porter is pretty well hidden below the spices. Very nice, but I would prefer an extra kick from everything.

4.0 T: The first sip was divine: awesome mixture of pumpkin pie, chocolate, and porter. However, as you drink this more, the thrill dies out. Its still very tasty, just not mindblowing like the first sip. The pie spices works really well with the chocolate, this might be something Ill need to brew. The porter comes through a lot mor in the taste than in the nose. Slightly charred roastiness with an otherwise clean maltiness.

4.5 M: Lighter medium to medium body. Would prefer a thicker body, but this is okay. Really creamy, which I love. Good here.

4.5 D: This is definitely among the better pumpkin brews Ive had. Id love to have this again. If it holds up well, I might as well trade for a lot of them. The dark flavors and chocolate are awesome with pumpkin and pie spices.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-23-2010 02:30:38

22oz. Bomber.  Deep brown pour with a decent layer of persistent tan foam.  Interesting nose that borders on medicinal with nutmeg, cloves, allspice and a hint of burnt chocolate.  Up front this beer is pure spice that is followed by some cocoa sweetness and hugely vegetal pumpkin.  The cinnamon and nutmeg are prominent in the flavor and there are layers of caramel that hit just before the chocolate notes.  The palate is well done, not thin and not too syrupy with a lively carbonation.  Has a dry finish reminiscent  of a strong porter.  Definitely well made even though its a bit unbalanced and overly spiced.

Reminds me of root beer. Lots of bubbles coating glass. Dark brown/black body. Brown head that falls fairly quickly. Aroma of ground spices, especially the nutmeg. Mouthfeel is thick. Flavors of nutmeg and cooked pumpkin and baked apples. Hints of light molases. I swear if I shut my eyes I can hear the crackling fire in the background and I dont have a fire place! :-)  As I grow older Im digging pumpkin beers less and less, but this one definitely is worth remembering.

Black pour, tan head.  Chocolate and pumpkin bread aroma, vanilla, pIe spice.  Every year for christmas, my brother gives me this delicious chocolate pumpkin bread.  This beer tastes like a liquid version of that bread.  The varius extra ingredients in this beer all come through distinctly and in balance.  The beer has q very mouth coating effect and lingerw in the back of the mouth.

Bomber shared by glouglouburp.
Appearance : Pitch black with a small creamy head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Great pumpkin spices and cacao. Very rich and envelopping.

Taste : Pumpkin spices with cacao. Light dark choco on the finish with roasted malt. Dry finish. Carbonation soft and silky.

Overall : Very well made. got consistently better as I was drinking it. Great mix between pumpkin and chocolate. Awesome nose. quite drinkable. Great carbonation. Best pumpkin beer Ive had followed by JP La Parcella. Awesome brew.

A- Body is a translucent dark brown hue. Pours with a minimal head-which quickly fades to a thin collar and little to no lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- The highlight of the nose is the pumpkin and associated spices. Pumpkin, cinnamon, brown sugar, nutmeg with a mild chocolate background.

T- Initially this is all pumpkin beer with pumpkin, brown sugar, cinnamon and nutmeg shining through. The finish is intersting as the spices fade and a slightly sour pumpkin flavor shines through with an equal strength cocoa flavor.

M- Medium carbonation, and a nice medium to heavy weight smooth, full body.

D- This is a very good, interesting brew overall- as the chocolate and pumpkin make an interesting combination of flavors.

Serving type: bottle
