Had side by side with the oak aged. Thanks a lot Vince for giving me the chance to try these beers. Pours dark with a small brown head. Hints of cinnamon and nutmeg are evident. A very good beer overall. Having tried side by side with the oaked aged, I am a much bigger fan of the oak aged.

This poured a very dark red/brownish color with a smaller beige head. Aroma was of medium roast, light chocolate, cinnamon and pumpkin flesh. All there, but none overwhelming at all. Flavor was of medium spices upfront, follwed by silky chocolate and then finishing with a nice vegetal pumpkin flesh taste. Such a great beer that they somehow found a way with all of these ingredients to meld well together with nothing being left out or standing out either.

A-pours a black liquid with a light tan colored head.

S-tons of pumpkin in the nose, a fair bit of holiday spice, nutmeg and a touch of cinnamon.  some dark malts in the back with hints of dark fruit.

T-the taste falls short of the huge nose, the pumpkin is subtle but present, the spices are the same, light nutmeg and cinnamon.  dark fruits seem to fade but still some juicy sweetness in the back.

M-insanely smooth and creamy body, medium weight, super smooth and light and easy carbonation.

D-this is insanely drinkable, the nose was huge and the flavors are more subtle but it just works.  great pumpkin ale that is so well integrated and smooth.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Black in colour with medium carbonation. Huge nutmeg and clove aroma, with some faint roasted malt and caramel in the background. The spices nearly overwhelm the flavour profile as well, with the nutmeg and cinnamon really taking charge. Some chocolate and caramel notes come into play on the back end. Drying and spicy on the palate. Unbalanced, but not too bad overall.

Bottle from savnac enjoyed along side the oak aged pumpkin porter.  Thanks ira!  Pour is nearly black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is fairly similar to oak aged with lots of sweet roasted malt and pumpkin spice up front with distant notes of coffee.  Flavor is sweet malt, molasses, and pumpkin spice up front with a bitter and slightly acrid finish.  The barrel aging seems to have taken the edge off of this one quite nicely.  This is not as smooth or well rounded s the oak aged.  Still solid and Im still excited to have had the opportunity to try both.

dark brown, thin white head. Light pumpkin aroma, roast and soft chocolate, cake-like. Flavor has more pumpkin, chocolate, lightly roasty finish. Well balanced, bit more porter than pumpkin when compared to Bullfrogs recent effort, but well balanced nonetheless.

Bottle. Pours black with brown head. Nose of cocoa, pumpkin, clove, cinnamon and lots of nutmeg. Taste is very spicy. Lots of initial nutmeg, cinnamon and clove. Pumpkin and cocoa are in the background. Nice body. Well balanced.

On draft at Bruery Provisions.  Nice spicy aroma of clove and cinnamon.  Dark brown in color with hint of ruby hue.  Nice light brown lasting head with good lacing.  Flavor explosion of chocolate, cinnamon, and pumpkin.  Kind of sweet finish.  Mild creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation.

Draft at Toronado San Diego with Linh. Big thanks to the bartender as this round was on him. Pours a dark brown with nice foamy frothy head. Aroma is sweet pumpkin spice and dark chocolate. Mouthfeel is extremely smooth with nice notes of pumpkin, spice, vanilla, chocolate, and cream.

Rating 200 of this brew.  On tap at Stone Brewing after a funeral of a 15 year old kid.  Great dark brown/black color.  Thin head.  Lots of chocolate and spice.  Cinnamin and nutmeg.  Not overly sickly sweet.  Very well done.

Fresh pumpkin nose, pie spices, vanilla.  Palate is porter-like, chocolately with a touch of roast. Very good.
From sample pour at local December 2010 tasting.

Bomber from Holiday Wine Cellar ($13.99).  HWC recently got several of the Midnight Sun brews but I had to wait few more weeks for this one to come in from Alaska.  Pours almost pitch black with a finger and a half of creamy dark brown foam that soon dissipates.  Aroma has considerable spice (the listed cinnamon and nutmeg stand out), roasted pumpkin, , some chocolate, and hints of vanilla and even smoke.  Flavor has more prominent chocolate up front and the pumpkin pie spice toward the finish and some roasted pumpkin/vegetable/malt and brown sugar in between.  Rather creamy mouthfeel with some nice tangy spice in the finish.  This is a unique and very good brew that I would like to have again, but I am not crazy about the price.  (198, 431)

Roast, pumpkin, spices and resin on the nose. Dark brown with ruby highlights, thick and frothy dark tan head doesnt last too long. Fairly clear. Nice medium roasty caramel sweetness and medium resin and floral hop bitterness. Spicy sweet attack with hops coming through in the middle. Long balanced finish, slightly dry. Medium body and carbonation. One of the best pumpkin beers Ive had.

Bomber from Brewforia website.  Tasted alone, then paired with a slice of Thanksgiving pumpkin pie.  Aroma is quite clove-y (is that a word?) and chocolatey, with almost no trace of pumpkin and a touch of booze.  Pours a near-black soupy dark brown with a moderate tan head.

Flavor is just seriously wacky, with tons of clove and allspice(?) overpowering any hint of pumpkin and throwing off most of the roasty/chocolate notes that would help the balance.  Much better when paired with pumpkin pie!  Not awful, but I wouldnt have wanted to drink more than half the bottle without the aid of the pie.

Served from a 22 oz bottle from OTM. Im so stoked Midnight Sun beers are available down in SoCal especially these seasonals. The appearance is a midnight brown with a small disappearing light tan head. The aromas are spicy with a nice nutmeg and clove being the dominant additions with the meatiness of the pumpkin also adding to the nose. The flavors are very tasty. A lot of spiced pumpkin that has a chocolate over coating that really mellows out the over intensity that sometimes plagues pumpkin brews. Nice mild roast malts, brown sugar, cinnamon notes in there too with a bit of creaminess that is like cool whip on the top of your pie. Really nice chocolaty flavor that melds everything together. The mouth is medium to full bodied. Lightly creamy. An incredible spiced brew, definitely my favorite to date. A great way to start out Thanksgiving.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2010 22oz bottle. Rating #194. Pitch black pour with a very creamy light brown head with some real nice lace left on the glass. Big sweet spice aroma, lots of cinnamon and nutmeg and a touch of pumpkin.  Real sweet flavor, wow, a little too sweet though, loads of nutmeg and cinnamon, but a little over the top for me. (1433)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
A: The pour is a dark brown color with a slight murkiness and turbidity to it. The head is a little more than a fingers worth and tan in color.

S: Lots of the base porter still comes through giving off a nice chocolate and roast aroma in addition to a bevy of spices. Clove, nutmeg, cinnamon, and all spice seem to be there.

T: The spices come through strongly in the flavor as well. Lots of nutmeg and clove without too much pumpkin flavor. Again some moderate roastiness and a fair amount of chocolate from the base recipe. As this one sits on the tongue theres a bit of a warming feeling, maybe its the alcohol, but it seems more like it comes from the spices.

M: The body is medium, nothing spectacular in either the positive or negative, with a moderate level of carbonation.

D: Theres not a ton of actual pumpkin flavor here (probably not helped due to this being a porter which masks the fairly subtle pumpkin flavor), but its still a nice beer.

[3369-20100902] 22floz bottle. Christmas spice aroma has mild mint hints. Black brown body with a long-lasting creamy tan head and some lacing. Tons of rich roasty spice malt in the flavour with a long aftertaste. Full body. Good.
(w/ Bobsy, jerc)

22 oz bottle.  Very dark brown pour, thick tan head.  Sweet pumpkin pie, cinnamon, chocolate, nutmeg, and roasted malt.  Creamy mouth feel. The flavors are quite nice, but dont seem to completely jive; nice beer, but a bit messy.

Bottle. [thanks, Ryan]
Pours deep dark red with a small, creamy, beige film head. Aroma has dark chocolate, pumpkin sweetness, light peppery and a bit of cinnamon. Lowish carbonation, rather fat and creamy palate. Sweet flavour, lots of dark chocolate, some pumpkin and vegetable notes even if they are hidden okay behind the chocolate. Light peppery and spicy. Okay dry finish. Fine for a pumpkin beer.

Bottle from jrahrer...thanks man.  Pours a dark brown-bordering on black with a small brown head.  This is one of the best smelling beers Ive ever had the pleasure to try...notes of pumpkin spice are beautifully integrated in to a rich, dark chocolate roast base.  Seemingly simple yet so well done that its hard to describe unless youve had it.  Palate is slick and full bodied...flavors are big roasted malts, dark chocolate and pumpkin pie.  Wonderful brew!

Incredibly intriguing and enjoyable pumpkin porter. Pours a chocolate brown with a decent head. This brew emanates a chocolate roast nose, but unlike many dark pumpkin beers, this one exhibits a delightful medley of pumpkin and pumpkin spices. Chocolate roast body with nuances of pumpkin and cinnamon and allspice and nutmeg, and perhaps some ginger and clove as well. Deliciously complex from the first sip to the last. Astounding that this is a whopping 7.8%. This belongs in the pantheon of memorable pumpkin beers that should be sought out each year.

Pours brown with a medium creamy light brown cap. The aroma is pumpkin pie with cinnamon, brown sugar, some nutmeg and clove. The flavor is rich and spicy with lots of cinnamon, cocoa, pie crust and some squashy vegetal flavors in the background. A little gingery with mild roasted malts in the finish that are covered up by the intense spices. A little harsh on the palate and chalky, but a real treat (no pun intended) for the pumpkin beer lover. One of my favorites.

On tap at Brouwers Cafe, pours dark brown / black. Aroma of pumpkin, roasted malt, licorice and booze. Flavour is essentially the same - I dont really like the hybrid between the pumpkin and imperial porter here, but its solid for the effort.

Another unexpected option from the awesome people @ Beer Revolution... This one is something.  First impression is trying to figure out what flavors are going on.  The aroma is an amazing spice mixture and some sweetness, and the taste is cacao and pumpkin chased by a spice rack, but in a good way.  The elements in the beer are fantastic, but as a whole, this odd beverage does not come together perfectly.

I was wary of this one, but it wa great. Subtle aroma of spices, cloves and pumpkin. Flavors more of chocolate than spices or pumpkin, though the pumpkin and cloves are noticeable. Very smooth, nice brown head and fairly dark color.  Not cloying, rather perfect palate. I think this beer is difficult to pull off but they did a great job.

Draft.  Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head with a small amount of lacing.  Aroma is pumpkin and cinnamon  with a bit of roastiness.  Taste is strong of pumpkin, cinnamon, and spices.  A little bit of roast coming through.  Medium body.  Light carbonation.

Bottle from Market of Choice. Black pour with an inch of tan foam. The aroma was pretty amazing, featuring a little pumpkin, and a lot of nutmeg, cinnamon and chocolate. One of the rare beers I can smell from quite a distance away. The flavor had a little more chocolate up front, with a nice spicy nutmeg kick and a pumpkin and clove finish. The clove is probably the most dominant flavor. Easily the best beer with pumpkin in it that Ive ever had.

No idea who brought this bottle to the DC gathering, but I thank them very much.  I am normally allergic to any pumpkin beers, but this one had an interesting aroma of nutmeg and chocolate cream pie, with a flavor of cocoa, spice and fruit that was not over the top.  Highly recommended.

22oz bottle, thanks ygtbsm94(?)  Brown-black body with small beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, cinnamon, allspice, some bittersweet chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet, bittersweet chocolate, some allspice.  Sticky medium-full body, low carbonation.

Lots of clove and all spice in the aroma. Very dark walnut color with no head. Interesting mix of flavors. Pumpkin, allspice, creamy molasses  with coco notes. Creamy mouth feel. Not bad but Ill not get again.

Very dark beer that pours like motor oil with a creamy brown head that dissipates moderately fast. Strong cinnamon and nutmeg on the nose with roast, chocolate and slight booziness coming through. Tastes rich of chocolate and pumpkin with a heavy residual sweetness, almost sickeningly sweet. Little to no hop bitterness. Palate is extremely full, but too sticky sweet.

Bottle:  Pours a dark brown with little to no real head.  Nose is spicey, heavy on the cinnamon and cloves before a little of the cocoa comes through.  Just a bit of the nutmeg.  The taste is spicey up front, again cinnamon and cloves play the major role.  A delicious chocolate syrup (ala taking a shot of Hersheys right out of the bottle) kick before finishing with the nutmeg.  Leaves a spicey, lingering cloves finish.  I cant really pick up any pumpkin until it warms a little more as it blends in very well.  Smooth and lots of character.  If available, Id drink this all the time.

Somewhat fresh Bomber.  Pours normal porter-color, low carbonation with a khaki head.  Aroma shows gingerbread at first.  Pumpkin definitely comes out though it is a strange clash with the malty chocolate notes.  A bit of oak detected too though I know this isnt oak-aged.  Perhaps a touch too much nutmeg for me, though I have a low tolerance for it.  The pumpkin scent is nice though.  Flavor is nice pumpkin pie spicing upfront followed by a creamy, full-bodied chocolate finish.  The flavor is pretty damn good on this.  Great mouthfeel too.  Not flawless but this lives up to expectations.

Bottle: Pours a dark black color with light head. The nose is spicy and roasty, lots of pumpkin and chocolate up front with some underlying spices. The flavor is chewy and roasty with a tart and hoppy combination that brings a good balance. Very nice beer, what a Treat....

Interesting nose of lavender, flavored coffee beans, honey, and...rum? Taste has got a lot going on. The first thing my tongue notices is the spice...nutmeg, cloves and cinnamon (just as the label indicates), then a slight chocolate wave...followed by a generous helping of pumpkin pie! Deliriously delicious and a fabulous effort to balance out all these ridiculously good flavours. I cant believe that this kind of brew works...but..it does! Taste it for yourself and see.

2010-09-02. Black body with a nice brown head. Aroma is spicy with notes of nutmeg, something anise like and hints of cinnamon. 7+ Flavour is similar, spicy overtones, hints at cocoa, sweet pumpkin in the middle, light roast and lingering spice in the finish. 7+ Smooth average to medium bodied palate. 3+ Pretty solid beer. Just a touch more pumpkin and a touch less spice would suit my own tastes better. Presumably 2009 Vintage, Bottle from Belmont Station, Portland

This one has just about everything in a good pumpkin beer that I could ask for. The flavors of spice, nutmeg, cocoa, pumpkin all really came through, as did the cinnamon, but all worked really well together, and nothing seemed to overpower the other. The head retention and carbonation were great and the beer only got better when it warmed up a bit. Im gonna have to get the barrel aged next time to compare.

22oz bomber courtesy of ditmier. Pours very black and inky in the glass with a poofy, beige head that has good retention and leaves little smidgens of lace. Aroma is full of ginger snaps, pumpkin pie, nutmeg. Very rich with a nice floral and roasty porter background. Taste is not super thick or rich but velvety smooth on the palate full of gingerbread, ginger snaps, pumpkin pie, burnt cherries. All of this on top of a beautiful porter body that is sessionable, little high on the carbonation that moves to cola like on the palate. Really good regardless.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown to black body with a small fizzy light brown head.  Smells like pumpkin pie.  Cinnamon, nutmeg, pumpkin meat, lighter roast and chocolate malts.  Great pumpkin flavor, restrained spicing with real, natural tasting, pumpkin meat.  Its like pie and coffee in the same glass!  Medium bodied with moderate fizzy carbonation.  Long lingering roast and spice finish.  Could use a bit more body I think.  Wonderful beer though all in all.  Not quite as good as the barrel aged version, but very solid.  I need more of this!
Earthy pumpkin aroma, heavy nutmeg. dark  Brown, small tan head. robust body, tingly with the spice, Strong pumpkin body, full throughout and very toasty.

Pretty good beer, almost great.  This beer has some excellent spicing.  Theres a ton of pumpkin pie flavor with extra spice, just right for a pumpkin beer.  However, the aroma also has a big cola note that is almost sickly sweet, kinda surprising for Midnight Sun since their beers seem to run drier than nearly any other brewery.  Theres some chocolate and caramel lurking in the mix, as well.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin.  Appearance could also be improved - the head dissipates quite quickly, leaving just a very dark brown to black body.  This is a very well done pumpkin beer, but it has a few problems.

Pours a dark brown, near black.  Thin tan head, not much lace.  

Nose has roasty malts, cocoa, cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla and pumpkin,  

Taste is equally complex, possibly the perfect pumpkin pie beer.  A nice baltic porter with the addition of pumpkin, chocolate, and pie spices.  

Medium to full body is delicately carbonated.  Drinks quite well.

Pretty dense pour, nice body. Aroma has a lot going on. Lots of pie like spices and sweetness with some roasted malts. Flavor is spicy, sweet, and a slight burn from some of the spices. A bit of ginger and clove. Fairly sweet finish and a touch of dryness. Nice.

Might be one of the best beers ive ever had, id quite possibly punch my mom for another drank. Had a huge body to it, but wasnt cloying, loaded with complex levels of spice, nice candy like orange and chocolate flavors. It was like Midnight sun was doing an impression of a southern tier beer, but it was good.
Reddish black color with tan head. Aroma cinnamon, nutmeg, cocoa, coca cola. Taste is toasty and roasty with some pumpkin notes and spices.  Pretty good.

Nice deep brown coloured body with a lot of tan head on top. Aroma of tons of spices including allspice, coriander seed, nutmeg, canella, cloves and perhaps a bit of cardamom. Medium-bodied; Biting malt and brown sugar flavours really come through with some curacao, a touch of nuts and a lot of the good spiciness. Aftertaste shows more spices, a lot of brown sugars and plenty of malt to round things out nicely. Overall, a good herb/spice beer that really shows well, especially for the Autumn season! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Brown Jug in Anchorage, Alaska on 23-June-2010, sampled at home in Washington on 01-July-2010.

(22oz bottle thanks to Exiled) clear dark brown with creamy tan head. Nose of cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, pumpkin, and chocolate wafers. Taste of moderately sweet chocolate, pumpernickel bread, pumpkin, star anise, with cola-like carbonation. Thinner body than expected but quite drinkable!

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle. 

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is pretty strong with notes of pumpkin and ginger. For the flavor I get chocolate, pumpkin pie spices (ginger, nutmeg, cinnamon and cloves) and some pumpkin. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very good beer.

22oz bomber, 2009 edition, courtesy of zminor on BA. thanks, zac! pours a dark brown with a thin cap of bubbly, dark beige foam leaving a tight ring of lace. aroma is great with big notes of homemade pumpkin pie filling, clove, and spicy cinnamon with hints of dark chocolate, burnt pie crust, and toffee malts. flavor is excellent as well with loads more chocolate, roasted malts, and light coffee coming through than in the aroma with a nice, subtle backing of nutmeg, cinnamon, and sweet pumpkin pie with a lingering, spicy, roasted finish. palate is medium bodied and nicely carbonated with a very solid balance of sweet/spicy/pumpkin/chocolate flavors with not too much of any element. overall, a great pumpkin beer.

Shipped to me by my wife on a trip to Portland. Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a large creamy brown head that lingered and produced good lacing. The aroma was strong cocoa, sweet cinnamon, nutmeg and raisin. The flavor was strong sweet chocolate syrup with notes of cinnamon, ginger and clove. The finish was long with cocoa and cinnamon. A bit of alcohol showed through. Full bodied and smooth. Excellent.

Bottle, shared with Parksy. Pours a hearty near-black with a decent brown head. Spicy dark chocolate aroma. Richly flavoured, with a balanced interplay between chocolate and pumpkin pie spices (nutmeg, clove). This remained tasty and interesting, leaving me wishing for more. Even Parksy (who hates pumpkin beers) really liked it.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
Cocoa and slight smoke aroma in opaque darkest brown brew with beige head (slightly metallic and low-carb from bottle-- thanks k.M.).
LIKE a mellow robust porter with cocoa and nutmeg)....melllow love

Bottle at Max and Andys Fantasy Tasting. - interesting take on a dark pumkin ale. Dark pour, arouma of cloves, cinnamon and pumpkin pie. Crispy sweet, and very dessert-friendly. Roasty, a touch of ginger and funk. Arouma >> taste

22 oz. bottle via trade with highibus - Pours a dark brown color with a nice size tan head.  Very light lacing.  Aroma is a nice blend of spices.  Flavor is chocolate, dark esters, and spice.  Its quite nice.  No unpleasant lingering aftertaste.  Medium body.  A real nice pumpkin beer.  Thanks Tom.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2012 Rerate on 10/28/2012.  Aroma of pumpkin, earth, chocolate, toffee.  Dark brown appearance, light tan head.  The flavor is like the aroma, pumpkin up front, chocolate, toffee, lifght roast.  medium in body, slightly thick, creamy mouthfeel.  Finish is pumpkin, spicy, roast, bittersweet chocolate.  Very good.

Black pour. Small head. Sweet chocolate, buttery toffee, nutmeg, pumpkin and lactose in the nose. Very nice!l  flavor of sweet cream, chocolate, nutmeg, brown sugar and hints of sweet oak (even tho it isnt there, I know...). Very appetizing and desert-like

Pours black with a nice tan head and a pumpkin aroma. There is a rich chocolate flavor with a lot of pumpkin and spice. Its pumpkin pie meets chocolate mousse, with quite a bit of carbonation. A complex and interesting brew.

Bomber poured a translucent dark brown nearly black with a lasting brown head. Aromas of pumpkin, cinnamon, toasted malt, cocoa, clove and nutmeg. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of pumpkin, cinnamon, clove, cocoa and nutmeg with a smooth lingering spiced finish. One of the best pumpkin beers Ive had!

Really delivers on the pumpkin, the choco, the spice, its all there in spades. Great (if not somewhat a novelty) beer! I think as the flavors are so deep, they dont really shine in the aroma. Flavor and mouthfeel is excellent.
bomber thanks to brewboone.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Nose is very potent with nutmeg, pumpkin, chocolate and smoke.  Taste is the same as the nose.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin and dry.

Bottle with Craig, who kindly supplied this beer (cheers mate) consumed at my gaff, day two tasting 09-04-10    Nose had a touch of sourness (possibly saison like) which didnt overly concern me being a porter but I know that Craig had his doubts as to whether this was in top nick. Pour was dark, dark brown almost black with light beige head. The flavour and aroma had a casual air about it, and at times came across as actually being quite delicate with perfume and floral notes detected in both nose and mouth. This was smooth, with light chocolate touches, gently spicey and was just really very nice.     A7 A4 F8 P4 Ov15  3.8

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2013 Bottle at home... August 2013...deep dark black... Small tan head...  Soft sweet spiced roast... Soft pumpkin nose... Soft roast... Light roast... Soft sweet pumpkin roast... Mellow smooth.. Loafs of pumpmin 4.3


bottle at fins ... and oh what a gusher :-( ... deep black ... big short lived brown foam head ... sour roast malt nose ... big chocolate ... definite pumpkin ...sourness ...  light nutmeg spice ...  good roast ...huge  even with sourness 3.6..such a shame the travel has impacted this. ...  TK2  bottle at home ... deep black ... short tan head ... sweet toffee malt ... huge pumpkin nose ... no sourness this time ... huge soft chocolate malt ... again loads of pumpkin but quite soft and well balanced into the chocolate roast ... light spice ... very mellow ... this is crackin ... i am so glad that i got aq 2nd crack at this one ... especally after waiting so long to get it the first time ... 4.1

Thanks to Brewolf for the bottle. Dark brown pour with a thick tan head. Clove, cinnamon, chocolate and pumpkin in the nose. Taste is chocolate, pumpkin, clove and cinnamon all bursting through. Really nice brew.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with a big brown head. Doesnt pour overly thick. Nose is pumpkin, clove, and nutmeg. Taste is similar plus cocoa. Good stuff.

Had this bottle since 2008, thanks to goryshkewych for originally hooking it up.  Pours dark brown with an off-white head.  Nose is roast, earth, slight coffee, chocolate, sweet pumpkin, spice, molasses, brown sugar, cinnamon, and sugar.  Flavor is similar with sweetness and spices prominent- pumpkin takes more of a backseat.  Medium body and sweet spicy chocolate pumpkin pie with a hint of roast in the finish.  Deep, complex, and moderately sessionable.
Big Pumpkin spice nose and creamy dark chocolate mouth.  Interesting disparity between what I smell and taste.  Nice medium body and moderate drinkability.  Overall, I like this beer.

thanks to dchmela for sharing!  Cocoa and pumpkin on the nose with hints of spices.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Smooth rich dark flavors bitter chocolate, pumpkin with clove and spices, cinnamon.  Very nice pumpkin beer!

Thanks to dave.  Pours dark, opaque, thin tan head, some ok lace.  Great nose with hints of roasted malts, pumpkin, and spices, particularly nutmeg, and even some hints of anise.  Flavor is pumpkiny, fairly sweet, but very good.  Everything is balanced so perfectly that the pumpkin doesnt overwhelm the great malt profile.  Very good beer.
Bottle.  Black color with a foamy brown head.  A sweet pumpkin spice aroma with cinnamon and cloves.  A light chocolate toasted malty flavor with nutmeg and warm spices.   A long sweet creamy finish.

Impressive beer.  I dont typically enjoy chocolate or pumpkin beers but this wa extremely enjoyable.  The spice is perfectly balanced with the afore mentioned chocolate and pumpkin.  Pours a very rich dark brown with a very small-bubble carbonated foam.  Was a great followup to the lasagna I ate prior.

22oz bottle.   Black with a medium tan head.   The aroma is a blast of pumpkin pie spices with a light chocolate maltiness holding it all up.   The flavor has plenty of sweet chocolate, light roast, and the same spices, though they are more in balance with the malt than in the aroma.   Sweet stuff, and a very dessert-oriented beer, though a tasty one.   A really cool take on the pumkpin beer, but maybe a little over the top in sweet and spice.

Bottle thanks to SuzyGreenberg! Pours black with minimal brown head. Aroma is full of spices (cinnamon and nutmeg), pumpkin and a slight chocolate undertone. Flavor begins with lots of spice and including cinnamon and nutmeg as well as pumpkin and a bit of chocolate at the finish.
Pours black with a thin tan head, lots of lace. Aroma-roasted malts, pumpkin, spices, milk chocolate. Taste- all of the aroma, plus a creamy, full bodied richness. Phenomenal brew.

Bottle courtesy ditmier. Pours a dark clear brown with a small beige head, unassuming but full of absurd spice orgy nonsense. Cinnamon, nutmeg, and clove are everywhere, flanked by pumpkin flesh. Pumpkin pie liqueur, perhaps? Flavor is similar to the smell, but with some more backing malts and a touch of smokiness. Easily the best pumpkin beer Ive had yet.

22 oz.  bottle tasted blind.  Pours dark brown with solid tan head.  Aroma of mint, cocoa, licorice and an off vegetal flavor.  Okay sweetness but a weird sweaty funk flavor and a bitter vegetal flavor.  Also finishes of licorice necco wafers.  Good carbonation.  Very complex beer but not drinkable.

Bottle courtesy of Pepsican. Pours a deep reddish with a good head and lace. The aroma is ginger and dark chocolate. Smells like delicious ginger cookies. Flavor is some pumpkin but lots of dark chocolate and spiciness. Pretty tasty stuff.
Not overpoweringly spiced.  Nice pumpkin aroma.  Classic liquid pumpkin pie, but not too sweet or cloying like a ST Pumking.
Black with a creamy tan head.  Pumpkin, spice, and chocolate aroma and taste with some very pleasant pumpkin pie tastes to the finish.  Quite good.

Bottle. Blackish beer with a small tan head. Christmas spice and light pumpkin aroma with sweet malt. Rich malt and mollases flavor with brown sugar, christmas spice and chocolate. Fulelr bodied. Chocolate and mollases lingers with ruch malt and christmas spice.

New bottle in Wine & Beer Haus, Seaside Oregon.  I was looking for a special beer for my 1111th beer since 2002 in their Hall of Foam Club.  Wow.  Pours with a nice dark head.  Has the chocolate & spice aroma, Tastes like a wonderful high end Stout w chocolate.  builds up flavor as it warms up.  A perfect beer for the occasion.

Bottle from after4ever. Huge thanks Tom! Pours a dark brown color with a small tan head. Nose is monster scents of nutmeg, cinnamon, chocolate, basic pumpkin pie flavors. My wife could smell it across the table! Palate is thick, creamy and smooth as silk. Flavors of pumpkin pie with a chocolate coating.  Light bitterness in the finish gives it a little extra texture. This is wonderful.

Bottle shared by pepsican. Thanks. Poured a nearly opaque brown color with red highlights. The head was light tan. Smelled of distinct clove, coffee, and dark chocolate. Medium bodied and sweet with notes of darkly roasted malt and cocoa.

Thanks to whomever brought  this to the Woodshop 5.0 tasting.

This beer had too many spices going on for me.

Pours dark brown, frothy light tan head.  Nose is pumpkin-pie spice, a little pumpkin itself, with underlying dessert-like sweetness.  Smooth, sweet flavors with touches of pumpkin and spice beneath...a little vanilla...a bit of the pumpkin squashy thing going on...nice pumpkin beer.

shared by a non-rb homie. pretty awesome stuff, the pumkin and spices really comethrough at the end of both the nose and the taste. nice velvety body, well balanced but for a tiny bit of heat present.  a very interesting winter warmer, i wish i could get more of this!

Bottle from City Beer, shared with some BA people there.  Pours darkest brown with a nice light tan head and great lacing.  Aroma is really great with pumpkin, spice, chocolate, roast, and molasses.  Flavor is really chocolatey with lots of pumpkin and spice, only mild roast.  Also some pumpernickel bread notes.  Medium-full body, extremely smooth and creamy on the palate.  This and the oak aged version are about as good as pumpkin beers get.

Wow deep black with cocoa head. Aroma is like nothing I have ever smelled before. Veggie and spice. Flavor has notes of cocoa and cinnamon and other spices. The pumpkin is more a vegetal quality. Really complements well. Lingering finish. Really nice beer.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 Courtesy of 5000 via trade
Bottle:  The aroma is a great combination of cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, chocolate, and just a hint of pumpkin.  It pours a dark brown with very faint orange highlights around the edges of the glass and a small tan head.  The flavor starts with with moderate amounts of chocolate.  The finish has light-moderate ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla, and just a hint of fruit.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.

pours a jet black with a small khaki head, and some lacing.

smell is of spice, some cocoa, and lots of pumpkin.

taste is of strong pumpkin, spice, chocolate, and a little bit of hops in the back, ends with a strong pumpkin aftertaste, and some bitterness.

22oz bottle.  Cola brown with a frothy off white / beige head, some spotty lacing left on the tulip.  Nutmeg, clove spice, cocoa dust and cinnamon on the nose.  Didnt pick up quite as much pumpkin on the nose as I was hoping.  Flavor is very similar, medium in body with some dry spices on the finish.

Bottle from Malt & Vine. Pours black with a two finger light tan head. Aroma is a pumpkin/chocolate combo. Full bodied with mildly foamy carbonation. Flavor is like pumpkin pie over chocolate pudding. Finishes pie spice - lots of cinnamon, chocolate and nutmeg. Incredibly rich. Amazing. Fantastical. Extremely enjoyable.

22oz Bomber  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia WA  
Aroma: Big spice nose with awesome backing from pumpkin and chocolate aromas.  
Appearance: Dark Brown in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Big spice with smooth pumpkin and chocolate flavors.  Not much else can get through this was so complex 
Palate:  Dry chocolate finish with a Good Mouthfeel.  
Overall: One of the better pumpkin beers to date. This is a big beer and I not for the weak.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep brown, cola hues, moderate to large foamy beige head, fairly sticky lacing. &nbsp Spicy nose, albeit there is a lot of pumpkin and not just cinnamon and nutmeg.  &nbsp Some chocolate and cocoa as well. &nbsp Good body, a little chewy, nice carbonation. &nbsp  This is really tasty. &nbsp Almost a Porter but without a heavy roasted malt. &nbsp Very creamy. &nbsp This is tasty! &nbsp Nice amount of sweetness. &nbsp Lingering spices. &nbsp This was one of the better Pumpin Ales I have had in a long time. &nbsp Flavorful, realistic, with a good body. &nbsp Recommended.

Bomber. Pours dark brown with one finger dark tan head. Aroma is clove, cinnamon, pumpkin spice, chocolate and roasted malts. Flavor is chocolate, molasses, clove, pumpkin, and some roasted malts. Finishes  sweet with some spice. Pretty solid pumpkin beer and a nice porter. Glad to have had the chance to try this beer with my brother on Christmas. Thanks Santa.

Purchased at East Pike Bottle Shop. 22 oz. bottle. Didnt have much of a viscous pour, but a nice black body with a slim head around the edge of the glass. Nice subtle chocolate aroma. Holiday aromas are coming through quite well i.e. I get a nice cinnamon aroma and a very nice clove spice aroma. Pumpkin is coming through in a subtle manner. Very nice nuanced aroma for a spice/herb/vegetable. Wow, this beer has a nice spice flavor that develops. There is a nice porter/stout roast and then with some time you have the cinnamon and clove developing. Ah...the cinnamon pumpkin flavor is very nice and leaves a lasting impression. Could have a SLIGHTLY better texture, but I think this is fairly decent.
Tap. Aroma is full of gingerbread and pumpkin, very intoxicating. Flavor is decent but palate is a bit of a let down given the aroma. Overall very good.

Was so excited when I saw this bottle at Malt and Vine!  Pours a deep brown with a caramel-orange, foamy head.  Aromas of bittersweet chocolate, cinnamon, clove, yeast, caramel and squash.  Palate is smooth and taste is superb.  Begins and ends with chocolate notes.  The chocolate lingers at the end, too.  Pumpkin pie spices are present but dont overwhelm.  A bit of earthiness, vegetable, and caramel enhance the flavor, but the definite treat of this one is its velvety chocolate ending.

All the roasty, chocolate goodness without the acrid and mouth-puckering bitterness so often found in spiced dark beers.  Pours with an espresso-crema-like head and jet-black body gives web like lacing around the edge of the glass.
Very well balanced flavors of cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg aka the pumpkin spices with the surprising addition of cocoa nibs and pumpkin.  A relatively full-bodied beer Im happy to see the low IBUS, relatively high ABV and ever so slight flavor of actual pumpkin.  Its in the initial nose and later more powerfully in the aftertaste..kinda like a hint of toasted pumpkin seeds, youll see... Thanks to Doug from Malt & Vine for the recommendation.  Prost!

Pours very dark brown and finally settles with a thin, mocha-colored head.  Aroma is thick with sweet cocoa, pumpkin pie, and autumn spice.  Flavor is also sweet, with pumpkin and chocolate swirling together nicely.  Cinnamon and nutmeg shine through.  The clove is actually discernible, and lends a nice zing to the smooth finish.  Very nice to sip, but seems to be going away rather quickly.  I will accredit that to the creaminess and the abv being below 8%.  How long does chocolate cake or pumpkin pie last when it is on your plate?  Same situation here.  Quite nice, and certainly worth the attention of anyone interested in a dessert beer that actually showcases the stated ingredients in a masterful way.  Yum.

22 oz bottle of the 2008. Black with a small tan head. Aroma is chocolate, pumpkin, and pumpkin pie spice. The flavor is bittersweet chocolate, pumpkin pie and some light hop bitterness. Full body with medium carbonation and a thick mouth feel. The chocolate really helps balance out the pumpkin, this is definitely a desert sipper. I prefer this fresh on tap, but this year old bottle is still excellent and holding up very well.

2008 Bottle Thanks to Toby. Pours out a black with some red highs topped with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, pumpkin pie, and spice. Taste much like the aroma more of the sweet pumpkin pie. The cinnamon and roast. Make this another treat from Midnight Sun.
dark brown with tan head.  lots of clove and nutmeg in the aroma with a thick sweet chocolate and pumpkin flavor.
Bottle shared by Hophead22.. Pours black with no head.. Aroma was pumpkins and molasses.. Flavor was pumpkins and chocolate.. One of the better pumpkin beers I have tried.

Bottle pours dark brown/black color with tan head.  Aroma is mainly cocoa.  Luscious mouthfeel.  Flavor is strong cocoa, pumpkin spices, coffee, chocolate, and finishes with a slight sweet aftertaste.  I didnt really get any pumpkin flavor at all.  I did notice the spices that were there.  Nice brew.

Sampled at Logans pre-GABF party.  Dark pour with a tan head.  Pumpkin, cinnamon, and chocolate aroma.  Understated pumpkin flavor, not overwhelmingly sweet like many pumpkin beers.  Some coffee flavor as well.  A very good pumpkin beer.

Yet another fabulous MSBC beer thanks to "AKfaust"! Colour... very dark brown with a lovely, thick, tan head. Nose... truly pumpkin-like (a damn rare thing in "pumpkin" ales and beers!) with plenty o pie spice and some molasses, to boot. Palate... Geez, what a pumpkin-spice monster! Loads of pumpkin, cinnamon, ground nutmeg and whole clove as well as vanilla, molasses, chocolate and roasted pumpkin seeds, all with a delightfully creamy mouthfeel and long finish! Not quite as good (in my opinion) as the oak aged version, but one of the finest pumpkin beers/ales ever!

2008 Bottle - Thanks Toby! - Pours dk brown with a medium beige head...aroma is light pie spice, dry cocoa, and roasty malt...flavour is similar, clove coriander and cinnamon...pumpkin and spice in the mouth right of the bat, with some dry malt, and roasty grain adding some bitterness midway thru...after having both versions now, I can now identify the difference, as this one retains a bit more bitterness...great stuff...

2008 version thanks to Toby. Pours a dark brown color with a medium brown head. The aroma is nice; sweet vegetable/pumpkin notes, spices and toasted malts. The flavor was great; chocolates and toasted malts meet spicy pumpkin and spices. Very drinkable and good. Very enjoyable.

Pour from a bomber courtesy, Gillard. Ive been wanting to try this for a long time, and it did not disappoint. The pours is a dark chestnut brown color topped by a small, bubbly tan head. The aroma shows hints of the rich cocoa and milk chocolate malt base to go with the cinnamon, nutmeg, and clove spices. There is a hint of fleshy pumpkin, but it is in the background. The flavor is similar with the rich milk chocolate base spiced with cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla. The fleshy pumpkin flavor pushes its way forward and blends in perfectly with the chocolate and spices and adds a hint of tartness to the beer. Full bodied and very creamy mouthfeel with a cocoa and cinnamon finish. This is one of the best beers with pumpkin I have had period. I would love to try this again and sample it next to the oak aged version.

Gillard shared this at Cigar City!  Dark brown pour, tan head.  This shit is better than the oak aged version! Aroma has some great chocolate, spices, pumpkin and some spice cake.  Flavor is light on the pumpkin with full chocolate and spice...very full flavored and very nice.
Blind tasting at PapsøsBlack color. Aroma of roasted malt and cinnamon; nothing impressive. The mouthfeel is quite smooth, some chocolate, light sweetness, cinnamon. Useless cinnamon sweet Stout.

Bomber, courtesy Gillard.  The pour yields a dark and cloudy, mahogany brown body with a small, foamy tan head.  Spotty lacing dots the glass.  The aroma is really nice, showing a milk chocolate, cocoa malt base, with complimentary spices of cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, and clove.  Pumpkin is there, but it is more subdued, which is a good thing in my book.  The flavor is similarly rich and warm, with a cocoa and brown sugar base spiced perfectly with vanilla and cinnamon, with a glint of crystallized ginger and fresh, fleshy pumpkin notes.  Theres a very faint twinge of tartness that I actually kind of dig in this brew, intentional or not.  Velvety and creamy on the tongue, the palate is almost lactic.  Damn good brew.  I put it on par with, or perhaps even slightly better than the oak aged version.

22 oz bottle, 2008.  Dark brown with a thick and foamy tan head.  Nose is clove, cinnamon, pumpkin and brown sugar; a touch sour with Bakers chocolate.  Smooth and milky with a sharp fizz.  Taste is chocolate syrup with earthy pumpkin and spices.  Kind of like an egg cream.  Finishes dry and vaguely vegetal.

Bottle 65cl. @ Papsoes blindtasting. [ Bottle #34. ][ Trade by GAManiac ]. Clear dark brown color with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, spicy, cinnamon, cardamom almost like a honey cake, cloves and nutmeg. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20090612]

Bottle and served in my Bells snifter: Deep brown with some reddish highlights, fading fizzy head and spotty lace. Wow, they did not skimp on the pumpkin or spices for sure, lovely combination of pumpkin and chocolate cream pie aroma. Even a hint of pipe tobacco and earthy yeast esters thrown about for extra fun and enjoyment. The taste is equally spicy, earthy and porter like. The chocolate and sweet malts are easy to find wrapped around all that pumpkin pie like flavors. The mouth feel is smooth and round but the finish is a bit ashy. Overall a damn solid brew and quite tasty. Mikey Likey this even more than Flossmoors Big Black Pumpkin.

Dark brown almost black with creamy tan head and lace. Pumpkin pie spice aroma dominates. Flat taste with a bit of pumpkin and an ashy like after taste. Medium full bodied with smooth carbonation. Another pumpkin spice beer that smells much better than it tastes. Very drinkable beer.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a lazing brown head. The aroma is very complex with notes of sweet malt, wood, fruit, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of soy sauce, wood, malt, alcohol, and caramel, leading to a dry woody finish. The alcohol tickles the tongue.

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a small, fizzy, dark brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, nutty, chocolate, cookie), light hop (dry grass), average yeast (leather, broth) with notes of pumpkin, nutmeg, and cinnamon.  Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a chalky finish.  Long duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2010 @Pilsner Petes East Coast Gathering-22oz bottlepours a tan head and dark brown color.  Aroma is dark malt-chocolate, pumpkin, spice/clove.  Taste is ashy which overrides, dark malt, spice.  Thanks notalush for sharing.  

100323-Tmpa wkly Gathering-rerate  3.5
#34 - Amerikaner Blind-Smagning 12-Jun-2009 hos Papsoe. Bottle. Black - brown head. Honning kage, cinnamon, spicy, honey, burned, roasted, vanilla, sweetness, light metallic notes. OK.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Dark brown with a warm reddish hue and a creamy light brown head. Spicy aroma, some roasted malt and vanilla. Medium body, sweetish roasted malt and spicy accents, very sweet. Hardly any bitterness. 120609

From bottle, blind #34. Pours dark brown to black with a small and slowly collapsing tan head. Dark toffee, roasted breadish and caramelish. Light metallic, roasted malt, breadish and light honey note. Smooth and slight bitter finish. Lasting fruity and roasted malt flavoured finish.

Deep brown beer with a thick sticky brown head.  The beer really does look incredible.  Big rich sweet aroma.  Lots of clove, allspice and nutmeg over a rich dark chocolatey roastiness.  There is a bit of espresso powder in the nose as well.  The flavour shows lots of spice as well as a fair bit of pumpkiny vegetal quality.  There is a touch of light tartness on the back also that kind of cuts the sweetness.  Its a damn tasty brew one of the highlights of the tasting.

Bottle #34 at Papsøs blindtasting. 
Black coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of honey cake, spices and chocolate.
Sweet and roasted flavour of spices and chocolate with otes of honey cake.
Roasted and spicy finish.

Pours mostly dark.  Aroma of pumpkin pie, crust, nutmeg, light roast, and light dark chocolate.  Flavor is a big mix of stuff with astringent coffee, dark chocolate and pumpkin pie, but nothing seems to gell.  Medium bodied, unremarkable texture.  My numbers seem to rate better than my words somehow.  Could be a great beer, but thats where the oak aged version comes in.

This is such a weird, weird beer. The nose is pure pumpkin pie, nice and strong. The flavor, however, is chocolate chips - cheap, waxy chocolate chips - and pumpkin pie. I cant say Ive ever wanted chocolate chips in my pumpkin pie. Or that combo in my beer.

Bottle at PPRBSG09.  Pours a dark brown with a small head.  Aroma is dominated by spices--allspice, pepper, cinnamon, nutmeg.  Flavor of roasted malt, some sweet notes, and lots of the spices mentioned above.  No real pumpkin flavor, just spices, but this is a solid beer.
8/4/8/4/15 (3.9/5)

Check my rating on the Oaked version for more detail--as they are very, very similar.  Soft taste, one-dimensional flavor.  Spices and mouthfeel are the highlight, but I wasnt blown away by this at all.

Bottle: Near black pour with a dense khaki head. Spicy aroma, yet soft- toasted ginger, mild cardamom and evident clove (not a phenol). A bit over carbonated for the a Porter. Nice malt depth meshes well with the subtle spices. Chocolate, cinnamon, clove, vanilla- reminiscent of carrot cake. Some mild roast on the back. Nice, but lacking a creamy texture and not quite as complex as I expected. A bit hyped up for me.

Bottle. Aroma very spicy up front, cinnamon and nutmeg, maybe a bit of roasted malt back there, but strikingly spicy. Flavor gets a bit more interplay between the porter and all the spices, though still spice-dominated. I guess that makes sense since its a pumpkin beer, but Id like more of the base beer to come through since they bothered to make it 7.8%.

Bottle at PilsnerPeters Spring Gathering.  Hot damn was I excited to see this one turn up.  Pours a nice black with a medium tan head.  Clean aromas of clove, cinnamon, pumpkin, and some other spices.  Nice carbonation, with a little bit of pumpkin coming through.  Light spicy clove finish, reminding me of Mexican hot chocolate. Really good.

Thanks to AmericanBrew for sending this my way - 2008 bottle shared at Peters NY gathering - foamy black pour - the pumpkin adds a very subtle complexity that gives a nice depth to the roasted malt and chocolate - very subtle, especially for something with "imperial" in the name - the flavor has a lot of dry cocoa up front, and a very mild pumpkin flavor that is enhanced by a mixture of spices (nutmeg, cinnamon, etc.) that arrives late - more subdued than I expected, but delicious none-the-less.

Sampled at the Ohio group tasting on DLD eve 09.  Black pour with a medium tan head.  Nose full of cinnamon, nutmeg and chocolate.  Cinnamon and spice flavor up front, then chocolate with a slightly bitter coffee finish.  Deserving of the hype.

22 oz bottle shared at crizays house

Credits goes to Mike I believe for bringing this back from Dark Lord Day but I could be mistaken.  Ever the enigma Midnight Sun has come through with a solid seasonal porter.  While I prefer mine with a bit more sweetness and spice it brings something new to the table.

Aroma / Appearance - The thin tan head and sticky black lacing trickle into a fluid body.  Heavily spiced squash, pumpkin, chocolate, and other autumnal aspects are as advertised yet need a bit more refinement in my opinion.

Flavor / Palate - Chocolate whipped cream sprayed generously over pumpkin pie accurately describes this beer.  The spicy finish reminds one of squash with a drizzle of butter.  Moist, spongy, and earthy, it captures most of the best parts of fall with only a few flaws.  As none of them are glaring it gets high marks across everything but the overall score.
Good stuff here.  Great creamy mouthfeel.  The ratio of pumpkin to chocolate to porter was just about perfect.  Very nice throughout.

(22oz bottle, 2008 vintage)  Pours an opaque black body with a small tan head.  Aroma of pumpkin, chocolate, cinnamon, and roasted malt.  Flavor of roasted malt, pumpkin, clove, caramel, and cinnamon.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2009 Bottle...  Poured black with a khaki head.  Aroma of squash and yeast.  Not as roasty as a porter could be.  Spiced nicely and well balanced with noticeable pumpkin.  Sweet, nutty finish.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured black with a copper head.  aroma of spice and dark roast.  flavor had spices, pumpkin, and chocolate.  light body and high carbonation.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2012 Bottle. Pours black with rich chocolate head. Aroma of cocoa, pumpkin, cinnamon and nutmeg. Flavor is much the same with a very nice sweet maltiness. Heavy mouthfeel with low-medium carbonation. Overall, outstanding beer!!!
Black in color with a good sized tan head. Aroma is pumpkin, pie crust, chocolate, cinnamon, and roasted malt. Taste is of pumpkin, roast malt and chocolate.
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Nose is pumpkin, nutmeg, pumpkin pie, meaty vegetables, sugar, and canned pumpkin extract. Taste is the exact same. Creamy foamy sort of mouthfeel and medium length finish.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2009 2008 Bottle (pre- T.R.E.A.T.) thanks to bu11zeye. Had back to back with the oak aged version. Pours with a creamy tan head over a black body. Aroma of chocolate, pumpkin, nutmeg, cinnamon, and cocoa powder. Taste is pumpkin pulp, cinnamon, light smoke and light chocolate. Light bubbles, a bit syrupy.

Bottle. Pumpkin pie spice, allspice, cinnamon, Libbys Pumpkin pie from the can, a little bit of coffee/cheap chocolate, pumpkin pie all the way through. A solid middle of the road pumpkin beer. Nothing bad, nothing great.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2009 bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  Black pour with a huge khaki head.  Nose of chocolate and pumpkin with roasted malts.  Very sweet flavor of pumpkin, spices and chocolate.
Bottle.  I was expecting great things from this beer, but it was just plain horrible.  I poured it out.  Im mad.

60 oz. growler.

This beer will release its true flavor and potential slightly below room temperature.  Pours a deep black with a dark tan head.  Wonderful aroma of chocolate, cloves, spices.  Extremely smooth taste, that concludes with pumpkin as an aftertaste.

One of my favorite beers from Midnight Sun.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2009 2007 vintage w/ J in Mammoth Jan 09.  Sampled this before the oaked version.  One of the coolest beers Ive probably ever had - it has mellowed quite a bit though...I had this a year ago and remember much much more spice/pumpkin.  These seem to hide behind the upfront "porter" flavor nuances with the age.  I cant get enough of this nose...Thanks Tim!

2008 Bottle.  Deep, dark beer with faint mahogany hints around the edges and a foamy brown head.  Cereal grain nose with some dusty chocolate hints.  The dusty chocolate follows into the beer, with some faint clove and cinnamon spice.

2008, 22oz. share. Black pour with a foamy, dark tan head, and good lacing. Nose exposes roasted notes and spice- mainly clove, nutmeg, and a little ginger snap. The flavor is an interesting combo of the spices, bakers cocoa, and touches of tobacco and wood. Interesting slant on the style.
Pours brown with a thin tan head.  Smells of vanilla, chocolate, spice, some pumpkin pie notes.  Tastes chocolatey and tarte with some nice rich malty undertones.  Decent.
Bottle.  Pours a deep brown body with a tan head.  Sweet roasted malt, pumpkin pie, cinnamon, nutmeg, light chocolate oak.  Crazy spin on a pumpkin brew.  I was very impressed.

Bottle graciously shared by SuzyGreenberg. Thanks Ben. The aroma is a fantastic mix of roasted malts, earth, pumpkin pie, and chocolate. Pours an almost black with a big tan head that settles into a nice foamy layer. Flavors of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, pumpkin pie, spice, and some sweetness. Some dryness on the palate lingers in the finish. Smooth and creamy. Like a liquid chocolate pumpkin pie. Simply delicious IMO.

Bomber shared by mreusch. Pours jet black with a thin skin of mocha bubbles and cascading lace. The nose is quite enticing: a blend of cocoa, pumpkin pie and pumpkin pie spices, cinnamon and cola. Medium-bodied with tongue tickling carbonation and a mildly grainy finish. The flavor is a dropoff from the nose: cocoa, cinnamon, cola, pumpkin pie and a bit of plastic thrown into the mix. Really nice nose; OK overall. Thanks for sharing this one with us, Matt.

I have been looking to try this beer for a couple of years and up until now have not been able to score a bottle.  I owe a huge thank you to Photekut for getting a bottle and sending it my way.  22 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a moderate light brown head that lasted through three-quarters of the glass and left nice lacing all the way to the last sip.  Very pleasant aroma of pumpkin, chocolate, light roast, and a few notes of coffee.  The flavor is equally lovely with pumpkin and chocolate as the main attributes, but with coffee, light roast, and milk sugar also present.  I did not taste any of the spices listed in the description, but that did not detract from my enjoyment of this beer.  Medium bodied and not heavy.  Fairly smooth at the finish.  Sometimes, finally having something that you have wanted for a while can be a let-down.  Thankfully in this case, the experience lived up to my expectations.

22oz bottle. Thanks again to HopHead84 for the tasting. Pours dark brown/black with a thin, light brown head, some lace. Smells spicy and sweet, chocolatey with some slight pumpkin. Tastes spicy and pumpkiny with good chocolate and roasted malt flavors. Lots of pumpkin but not overwhelming. Full body, somewhat syrupy, smooth carbonation.

Dark brown. Small, quickly diminishing light tan head that lasts decently. Nice nose. Flavor has some richness and depth to it uncommon in a pumpkin porter. Very smooth, with an elegant mouth feel. Still doesn’t quite have the loads of extracted flavors I prefer, but still has some nice chocolate and pumpkin notes. Nice pumpkin ale overall.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 22oz bottle courtesy of alaskajoe poured into a snifter.

Pours dark, dark brown out of the bottle and settles in as pitch black in the glass underneath a large tan head that holds as a cap for a while and leaves decent lacing.

The is very interesting with the light pumpkin pie aromas of pumpkin, nutmeg and hints of cinnamon. There are some dark malts in there as well as chocolate though the spices stand out.

The taste is even more interesting to me. It starts with some chocolate and lactose sweetness up front before the pumpkin and spices roll onto the palate. The finish almost seems a bit smoky with some coffee bitterness as well. Really complex taste.

The mouthfeel is decadent with a very smooth feel with good carbonation and everything is just silky and dessert-like.

Its probably not a fair comparison but this is, without a doubt, the best pumpkin-infused beer Ive ever had. Very drinkable with a completely non-existent alcohol presence.

Shared by mreusch, thanks. 2008 bottle. Pours completely black with a small but strong tan head. Aroma starts smoky and woodsy with a little bit of toned down pine tree. I get lots of bacon-y woodsiness, I actually get BBQ ribs with a bit of pine, nutmeg and clove at the end.  Its very weird and original.  I am not smelling rauch malt but all these different aspects just come off this way.  Taste is less interesting though. Its a but watery with light chocolate, spices, and a bit of a nuttiness. Some burnt chocolate as well. Not heavy at all, goes down well with a medium body.  Love the aroma but needs some more of the flavor to really make this special.22oz bottle, New Belgium large snifter/goblet glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text:
2008 vintage, 22oz. bomber with thanks to NoonanDBarbarian on BA. Pours a dark brown with a fizzy one finger tan head, nice lacing, moderate retention 
Aroma is pretty intense, with nutmeg, allspice, milk chocolate, pumpkin, and rich fresh cream, maybe some eggnog too. Stellar aroma! Flavor has some sweetness, with fresh pumpkin puree coming more to the forefront, followed by lighter background notes of nutmeg, spice and chocolate. The flavor can’t seem to keep up with the aroma on this one.  Decent, but can’t help but feel let down from what the aroma eludes to.  Thanks for the chance to try Brian!

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2009 bottle from buddy in anchorage...2008 pours a normal dark with nice tan head.   smell wasnt as strong as anticipated, but still had a faint smell of chocolate and  sweetness.  Taste was of bitter chocolate and pumpkin infused together.  very interesting indeed.  Low carbination i did taste some hoppiness as well.  very different, but nice beer.  First Rating 3.7









Re-Rate 2009.  Pours dark with a nice tan head.  Smeel seems more aromatic for some reason.  Taste is pumpkin and spices all the way.  Nice creamy mouthfeel with a bit of an aftertaste of hops.  Dry finish but I just love the sweetness of this beer.  

I lost a bottle during the voyage from Anchorage, but at least I got one from the box along with a couple more goodies from Midnight Sun.

22 oz. bottle - thanks to my main man AKBelgianBeast for this one; 2007 vintage; wowzers, so incredibly tasty that i almost cant believe i shared this one with others!!  haha, just kidding of course; dark brown with soft, thick texture; soapy head brings out rich aromas of chocolate, roasted malts and pumpkin spice; very roasty and pumpkin is a calming addition that sits there softly, while providing a very welcome mix to the flavors and spice as a complement; chocolate is dominate and the pumpkin ends up more like roasted pumpkin seeds; and we can all remember from our childhood how tasty baked pumpkin seeds are; so smooth and a perfectly constructed beer; i hope that MS does something with the base chocolate porter; maybe my fav porter, fav pumpkin and fav chocolate beer all rolled into one; just divine; cant wait for the 2008 batch!!
A huge thanks to Guerde for sharing.  One of the best pumpkin beers I’ve ever had.  Phenomenal pumpkin pie intermingles with light chocolate malts.  A similar body with a smooth finish.

22 of the 07. Thanks, SuzyGreenberg! What a total score! Opaque black. Towering, surging, moussy tan head. Nice sheeting lace, but its appearance is brief. Coffee, chocolate, and pumpkin on the nose. Creamy medium body, woolly carb. Nice sweet pie spice, pumpkin, chocolate, and coffee on the mid-palate, in that order. Every flavor is distinct and well-manifested, but in harmony with all the others. It’s actually tough to focus on any one of them because they’re all so forward and pleasantly so. Long spicy chocolate finish. Wow. Astonishing.

Courtesy of Geiger.
2008 bottle, pours black with brownish head.
Aroma is spicy, pumpkin and chocolate.
Taste had more chocolate notes with pumpkin in the aftertaste. One could also note many spices that reminded me of a winter warming beer. Notably cinnamon, nutmeg.
Everything was very well balanced, neither too much of chocolate nor pumpkin. An exceptional beer.

Bottle shared by thickfreakness.  Thanks dude!  Pours a dark black color with a tan head.  Smell is like a tootsie roll at first, and then opens up into a chocolate pumpkin pie like smell with definite pumpkin coming through.  Taste has lots of nutmeg as well.  Unique mix of flavors.  Good, but a bit strange.  Still, I liked it overall, for an oddball beer, but not something I’d reach for often.

Pours black with a tan head that retains very well and leaves good lacing behind.  Smells of cinnamon, charcoal, pumpkin pie, chocolate, and clove.  Chocolate, pumpkin pie, cloves, nutmeg, caramel, brown sugar, and a touch of ginger.  A touch less than medium body and lighter than medium carbonation.  This is a really tasty and fun beer, wish I could get this more regularly.  Thanks to AKBelgianBeast for the bottle.

22oz bottle generously donated to our worthy drinking cause by Stine.  Amazingly rich nose of chocolate pumpkin - I guess they nailed that aspect - along with some sweet and sugary chocolate donut notes and some sweetened pumpkin.  At slightly warmer temp the sweet nose turns more towards true pumpkin pulp and meat, more towards a chocolate squash quality.  Flavor is at first roasted pumpkin and greenish squash, then chocolate malt - not heavy but not light - and roasted barley... body is moderately thin, surprisingly, but it still stands up well.  Dont want to say watery, just thin it seems... finishes smooth and pleasant with notes of clove and nutmeg.  Really a unique experience.

Courtesy of stine. Dark brown/black body with  a small tan head. Damn, thats a lot of pumpkin. Some chocolate and molasses, but mostly pumpkin pie. Slightly sweet with little bitterness. Lots of pumpkin and spice, sort of dominates the chocolate, brown sugar and toffee. Medium/full body is soft with light carbonation. A bit much for me, but not too bad.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 22oz bottle, generously left behind by Stine.  Thanks so much, Eben!  Pours a dark, chocolate-brown color; fluffy medium-tan head with solid retention and fine-bubbled lacing; a solid pour.  Soft spicing (cinnamon, nutmeg), milk chocolate and pumpkin in the aroma; very mildly bitter chocolate and nougat; quite nice.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy clove and nutmeg upfront; soft dark chocolate and bitter chocolate; relaxed carbonation; the pumpkin and spice presence is nicely integrated into the roasted, chocolatey porter core; very drinkable and very tasty, warming stuff (no show of alcohol).  Lengthy finish: soft milk chocolate, roasted malts, and very delicate spicing (cloves, nutmeg); beautifully done pumpkin beer.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2008 [Bottle, thanks Guerde!] Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is more like a fresh baked pumpkin than a pumpkin pie, but the spices (nutmeg and cinnamon) are also very evident. Taste is a little peppery, but otherwise deep roast, the same real pumpkin as before and nutmeg and cinnamon again. Medium-thin with a long pumpkin finish. A good beer, although a little different than I had imagined it would be.
Black beer.  Roasted aroma with a roasted grain flavor mixed with good pumpkin pie spices including nutmeg and some cinnamon.  Good, full palate.

Small sample at OSLO and Guerdes tasting on Friday, 5-23-08. I can smell the pumpkin from a foot away. Pumpkin, pumpkin spices, pumpkin pie, and chocolate scents. Pours brown with a red hue. Sweet taste features chocolate and cherry flavors. Light to medium body.

(bottle, from gunhaver) Pours dark brown with a scant off-white head. Im initially greeted with a great baked pumpkin pie aroma with clove as well, but then the porter side of the beer takes over, and scents of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee replace the pumpkin which exhibits a good contrast.  The taste is very balanced as well, with all of the porter aspects of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt making up the flavor.  These malts are teetering on the edge of being too charred and harsh, but somehow they pull it off.  Now at this stage, one would think theyre drinking just an ordinary heavy-roasted porter, but then the amazing finish comes in to remind you youre drinking this great hybrid beer.  The finish is just a dominating dose of baked pumpkin that I really enjoyed.  Even though this beer was somewhat thin, the finish more than made up for it.

Big thanks to Guerde. Unknown fact about me: I am not a big fan of pumpkin beers as most of them seem to exhibit some phony spice shit that makes me think I am inhaling fumes from some chemistry project gone awry. Lets talk about a pumpkin scratch and sniff that has been stuffed into a beer bottle and then some nasty lager poured into it. BUT not this Pumpkin Porter. This sucker had me thinking I had just gotten off the sleigh at Grandmothers house and had opened the door to the smell of freshly baked pumpkin pie. This was actually very tasty, all kidding aside.

OSLO and Guerdes Memorial Weekend Tasting, 5/23/08.  Thanks to Guerde.  Black color with a thin head.  Lots of cloves, alspice and chocolate in the aroma.  The flavor is even better than I was hoping for... nutmeg, cloves, light ginger, along with actual pumpkin.  Very dry chocolate.  For being Imperial, the alcohol was barely noticeable.  Yum!

Poured from a 22 oz. bottle, warm chocolate brown with a glow of ruby around the rim.  Some leafy spice in a chocolate and pungent pumpkin warmed aroma.  Flavor is full of cocoa, vanilla beans, floral spice, and nutmeg.  Pumpkin warmth is slow to arrive but lends a rich, unique sweetness in the mid palate.  Roasted rustic character tends to temper the adjuncts quite perfectly, not wholly silencing them but simply reining them in a bit.  Palate is crisp and medium in body; warm and generous with a feathery touch.  Finishes with a decadent spicy sweetness that tapers off reticently, slowly.  Amazing balance throughout.  Gorgeous.  Thanks Andy!

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 Sampled at OSLO/Guerdes Memorial Day tasting. Shared by both Olso and Guerde. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a fast dissolving beige head that dissipates to a fine film and no ring. Aroma of toasted dark malt, some nutmeg and mincemeat pie filling, cloves and a touch of cinnamon. Taste is toasted dark malt, nutmeg/cloves with a touch of cinnamon. Finish is toasty dark malt and some clove aftertaste. Not much in pumpkin flavor but definitely the pumpkin spice and character.

Courtesy of gunhaver. Pours deep brown with tan head. Yep, as expected the aroma has a lot of notes as pointed out in the name of the beer with chocolate, roasted malts, pumpkin and pumpkin pie spices. I think the notes go pretty well together. The taste has pumpkin mixed with dark roasty malts and some rich dark chocolate and malt roastiness. Nice tasting brew that would go nicely for dessert.

Thanks for sharing Jake.  Just not a big fan of this beer.  I think part of this has to be with the fact that I am just not a big fan or the style, or porters in general.  Rich caramel maltiness, with some pumpkins spices int he background, with a bit of mild cinnamon and anise.  The finish is slightly bland and quite thin.

Bottle courtesy gunhaver. Pours black with a small tan head. Huge aroma of pumpkin pie, roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is the same as aroma with a touch of caramel. Medium full mouthfeel with a mild to moderate amount of bitterness and smooth alcohol. Strange and different but good.

22oz bottle, 7.8% ABV, 30IBUs, Vintage 2007.  Pours dark brown.  Big pumpkin pie aroma.  nice spice.  Chocolate - pumpkin.  Flavor is rich squash flavors.  Great character.  Finishes with chocolate.  I just love pumpkin beers.
Chocolate, spice and pumpkin aroma.  Super rich pumpkin pie flavor.  Very little hoppiness; dry and tart finish.  A unique beer with a long name, but its great tasting stuff!

From a 22oz Bottle.  Mostly transparent, fudgey dark brown colored pour with a thick head of creamy tan.  

Wonderfully complex, pumpkin pie nose that brings out elements of ginger and nutmeg spice among a rich toffee malt 

base.  If anything, the ginger is a smidgen strong for my liking, but I find myself especially sensitive to this 

brewing ingredient and this is definitely on the more conservative end of the ginger beer spectrum.  Freshly baked 

pecan pie, brown sugar, and a light chocolate nougat malt richness in the middle.  Medium bodied, lightly 

carbonated mouthfeel with a creamy texture.  Flavors of chocolate fudge up front, rich and silky, softened by a 

smooth vanilla toffee character.  Nutmeg, cinnimon, and ginger spice clearly visible, but soft and accenting, 

melding perfectly with the ample malt base.  Perfect palate - silky smooth texture with an incredible malt base 

and superb pumpkin pie spice balance and clean execution.

Black with edges of brown.  Lumpy, dirty-gray head slowly scatters, but holds fairly well.  Chalky roast and coffee comprise the straightforward aroma.  Smidgeon of nutty malt, blackcurrants and nutmeg.  Fluffy carbonation gently prickles the tongue.  Dense estery fruitiness and tangy molasses fend off the sharp roast at first sip.  Understated spices impart a vivacious brightness which exaggerates the dryly chalky roastiness.  Somewhat grainy, though a large portion of the brash roast is absorbed by the residual sweetness.  Dirtiness becomes more apparent by the sip, as tacky yeast tangles with overripe plums to contribute an unpleasant limpness to the body.  Nutty java and smoky roast remain assertive, however, and continue to accentuate the brash roast.  Still, the malts fail to produce any noteworthy depth or complexity.  Spiciness augments the dryness, as does the bristling roast.  Tight note of cinnamon lifts the sweetness, although an inordinate amount of tackiness remains glued to the back of the palate.  Finishes with a crunchy note of char amid a lingering blend of soggy caramel-drenched grains, nutty malts and oily java.  Not a poorly made beer by any means, but certainly leaves room for improvement. Perhaps a bit grainy, yeasty and worty for me.  Shame that real pumpkin wasnt employed, as the  starches couldve acted as a counterpoint to the sharp char and graininess.

text: Poured black with a creamy tan head.  The first aromas to hit me  was of ginger and cinnamon.  Then a nice roasted malt underneath.  Roasty malt flavor with pumpkin pie spices. This spiced porter pours a dark brown color from a 22oz bottle. Medium sized tan foamy head. Aroma is chocolate, pie spices, cinnamon and pumpkin. A medium bodied ale. Very interesting. Tastes like a cross between an Imperial Stout and a pumpkin beer. Lots of chocolate and pumpkin flavors intermix with a bunch of coffee and roasty malts. Nice beer. I wish more breweries would make weird beers like this, well a lot do but not many work as well as this one. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet. Again thanks to Chris C for sharing this one.

My sis brought me home this bottle from Alaska. What a wonderful surprise! Pour is pitch black, with a large, late-rising, lovely brown head. The aroma of this beer is rather dissappointing, unassertive and almost not even there... mild milled grains, toast, slight vanilla, peanut brittle. There is a lot more going on in the flavor, though: chocolate, bitter herbs, nutmeg, a touch of pumpkin, peanut brittle. This beer is ultimately brought down by a sub-par palate... it is slightly thick, though not enough so, but more importantly it has a sharp metallic twang and dull aftertaste, the prior which gets in the way of what would likely be a more complex flavor. By the description, and knowing this brewer, I was hoping Id be able to drop a 4.5+ on this beer, easy. Ultimately, its rather dissappointing. In fact, when it was freshly poured and still cold (around 50), there were very intruiging chocolate and cherry notes that I was sure would come out as it warmed. Instead, they faded into the background, behind the metal shield erected around the brew.

Ah well.
